titleStmt.title: The TRAGEDIE OF Troylus and Cressida.

respStmt.name: Payge Temple with homographing and regularisation by Alexis Antonia

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Troilus Cressida Ulysses Pandarus Thersites Hector Agamemnon Achilles Ensemble Prologue
Nestor Aeneas Diomedes Paris Ajax Patroclus Cassandra Alexander Calchas Helen
Priam Servant Andromache Menelaus Helenus Margarelon Deiphobus Boy Soldiers Man Myrmidons

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

sp.l: IN Troy there lies the Scene: From Isles of Greece
The Princes Orgillous, their high blood chafed
Have to the Port of Athens sent their ships
Fraught with the ministers and instruments
Of cruel War: Sixty and nine that wore
Their Coronets Regal, from the Athenian bay
Put forth toward Phrygia, and their vow is made
To ransack Troy, within whose strong immures
The ravished Helen, Menelaus Queen,
With wanton Paris sleeps, and that is the Quarrel.
To Tenedos they come,
And the deep-drawing Bark do there disgorge
Their warlike fraughtage: now on Dardan Plains
The fresh and yet unbruised Greekes do pitch
Their brave Pavilions. Priams six-gated City,
Dardan and Timbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,
And Antenonidus with massy Staples
And corresponsive and fulfilling Bolts
Stir up the Sons of Troy.
Now Expectation tickling skittish spirits,
On one and other side, Troian and Greeke,
Sets all on hazard. And hither am I come,
A Prologue armed, but not in confidence
Of Authors pen, or Actors voice; but suited
In like conditions, as our Argument;
To tell you (fair Beholders) that our Play
Leaps over the vaunt and firstlings of those broils,
Beginning in the middle: starting thence away,
To what may be digested in a Play:
Like, or find fault, do as your pleasures are,
Now good, or bad, it is but the chance of War.

sp.speaker: Troylus.
sp.l: CAll here my Varlet, I will unarm again.
Why should I war without the walls of Troy
That find such cruel battle here within?
Each Troian that is master of his heart,
Let him to field, Troylus alas hath none.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Will this gear never be mended?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: The Greeks are strong, & skilful to their strength,
Fierce to their skill, and to their fierceness Valiant:
But I am weaker than a woman's tear;
Tamer than sleep, fonder than ignorance;
Less valiant than the Virgin in the night,
And skilless as unpractised Infancy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Well, I have told you enough of this: For my
part, I will not meddle nor make no farther. He that will
have a Cake out of the Wheat, must needs tarry the
grinding.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Have I not tarried?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Aye the grinding; but you must tarry the bolting.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Have I not tarried?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Aye the bolting; but you must tarry the leavening.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Still have I tarried.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Aye, to the leavening: but here is yet in the word
hereafter, the Kneading, the making of the Cake, the
heating of the Oven, and the Baking; nay, you must stay
the cooling too, or you may chance to burn your lips.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Patience herself, what Goddess ere she be,
Doth lesser blench at sufferance, than I do:
At Priams Royal Table do I sit;
And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts,
So (Traitor) then she comes, when she is thence.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Well:
She looked yesternight fairer, than ever I saw her look,
Or any woman else.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I was about to tell thee, when my heart,
As wedged with a sigh, would rive in twain,
Lest Hector, or my Father should perceive me:
I have (as when the Sun doth light a-scorne)
Buried this sigh, in wrinkle of a smile:
But sorrow, that is couched in seeming gladness,
Is like that mirth, Fate turns to sudden sadness.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
And her hair were not somewhat darker than
Helen's, well go to, there were no more comparison between the Women. But for my part she is my Kinswoman, I would not (as they term it) praise it, but I wold
some-body had heard her talk yesterday as I did: I will
not dispraise your sister Cassandra's wit, but ---

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O Pandarus! I tell thee Pandarus;
When I do tell thee, there my hopes lie drowned:
Reply not in how many Fathoms deep
They lie endrenched. I tell thee, I am mad
In Cressids love. Thou answerest she is Fair,
Pourest in the open Ulcer of my heart,
Her Eyes, her Hair, her Cheek, her Gait, her Voice,
Handlest in thy discourse. O that her Hand
(In whose comparison, all whites are Ink)
Writing their own reproach; to whose soft seizure,
The Cygnet's Down is harsh, and spirit of Sense
Hard as the palm of Plough-man. This thou tellest me;
As true thou tellest me, when I say I love her:
But saying thus, instead of Oil and Balm,
Thou layest in every gash that love hath given me,
The Knife that made it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I speak no more than truth.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Thou dost not speak so much.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Faith, I will not meddle in it: Let her be as she is,
if she be fair, it is the better for her: and she be not, she
has the mends in her own hands.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Good Pandarus: How now Pandarus?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I have had my Labour for my travel, ill thought
on of her, and ill thought on of you: Gone between and
between, but small thanks for my labour.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: What art thou angry Pandarus? what with me?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Because she is Kin to me, therefore she is not
so fair as Helen, if she were not kin to me, she would
be as fair on Friday, as Helen is on Sunday. But what
care I? I care not if she were a blackamoor, it is all
one to me.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Say I she is not fair?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p:
I do not care whether you do or no. She is a
Fool to stay behind her Father: Let her to the Greeks,
and so I will tell her the next time I see her: for my part, I will
meddle nor make no more in the matter.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Pandarus?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Sweet Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Pray you speak no more to me, I will leave all
as I found it, and there an end.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Peace you ungracious Clamours, peace rude sounds,
Fools on both sides, Helen must needs be fair,
When with your blood you daily paint her thus.
I cannot fight upon this Argument:
It is too starved a subject for my Sword,
But Pandarus: O Gods! How do you plague me?
I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar,
And he is as tetchy to be wooed to woo,
As she is stubborn, chaste, against all suite.
Tell me Apollo for thy Daphnes Love
What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we:
Her bed is India, there she lies, a Pearl,
Between our Ilium, and where she resides
Let it be called the wild and wandering flood,
Ourself the Merchant, and this sailing Pandar,
Our doubtful hope, our convoy and our Bark.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: How now Prince Troylus?
Wherefore not afield?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Because not there; this woman's answer sorts.
For womanish it is to be from thence:
What news AEneas from the field today?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: That Paris is returned home, and hurt.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: By whom AEneas?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Troylus by Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Let Paris bleed, it is but a scar to scorn.
Paris is gored with Menelaus horn.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Hark what good sport is out of Town today.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Better at home, if would I might were may:
But to the sport abroad, are you bound thither?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: In all swift haste.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come go we then together.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Who were those went by?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Queen Hecuba, and Hellen.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: And whether go they?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Up to the Eastern Tower,
Whose height commands as subject all the vale,
To see the battle: Hector whose patience,
Is as a Virtue fixed, today was moved:
He chides Andromache and struck his Armourer,
And like as there were husbandry in War
Before the Sun rose, he was harnessed light,
And to the field goes he; where every flower
Did as a Prophet weep what it foresaw,
In Hectors wrath.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: What was his cause of anger?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The noise goes this;
There is among the Greekes,
A Lord of Troian blood, Nephew to Hector,
They call him Aiax.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Good; and what of him?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: They say he is a very man per se and stands alone.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: So do all men, unless they are drunk, sick, or
have no legs.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
This man Lady, hath robbed many beasts of their
particular additions, he is as valiant as the Lion, churlish
as the Bear, slow as the Elephant: a man into whom
nature hath so crowded humours, that his valour is crushed
into folly, his folly sauced with discretion: there is no
man hath a virtue, that he hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint, but he carries some stain of it. He is
melancholy without cause, and merry against the hair,
he hath the joints of everything, but everything so
out of joint, that he is a gouty Briareus, many hands
and no use; or purblinded Argus, all eyes and no sight.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p:
But how should this man that makes me smile,
make Hector angry?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They say he yesterday coped Hector in the battle and stroke him down, the disdained & shame whereof, hath ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Who comes here?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Madam your Uncle Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Hectors a gallant man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As may be in the world Lady.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What is that? what is that?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Good morrow Uncle Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Good morrow Cozen Cressid: what do you talk
of? good morrow Alexander: how do you Cozen? when
were you at Illium?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: This morning Uncle.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
What were you talking of when I came? Was
Hector armed and gon ere yea came to Illium? Hellen was
not up? was she?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Hector was gone but Hellen was not up?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Even so; Hector was stirring early.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Was he angry?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: So he says here.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
True he was so; I know the cause too, he will lay
about him today I can tell them that, and there is Troylus
will not come far behind him, let them take heed of
Troylus; I can tell them that too.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: What is he angry too?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Who Troylus?
Troylus is the better man of the two.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: O Iupiter; there is no comparison.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
What not between Troylus and Hector? do you
know a man if you see him?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Aye, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Well I say Troylus is Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Then you say as I say,
For I am sure he is not Hector.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No not Hector is not Troylus in some degrees.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: It is just, to each of them he is himself.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Himself? alas poor Troylus I would he were.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: So he is.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Condition I had gone barefoot to India.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: He is not Hector.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Himself? no? he is not himself, would he were
himself: well, the Gods are above, time must friend or
end: well Troylus well, I would my heart were in her body; no, Hector is not a better man than Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Excuse me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: He is elder.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Pardon me, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
The others not come to it, you shall tell me another tale when the others come to it: Hector shall not
have his will this year.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: He shall not need it if he have his own.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Nor his qualities.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: No matter.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Nor his beauty.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: It would not become him, his own is better.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You have no judgment Niece; Hellen herself
swore the other day, that Troylus for a brown favour (for
so it is I must confess) not brown neither.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: No, but brown.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Faith to say truth, brown and not brown.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: To say the truth, true and not true.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: She praised his complexion above Paris.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Why Paris hath colour enough.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: So he has.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p:
Then Troylus should have too much, if she praised
him above, his complexion is higher than his, he having
colour enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a
praise for a good complexion, I had as lief Hellens golden tongue had commended Troylus for a copper nose.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I swear to you,
I think Hellen loves him better than Paris.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Then she is a merry Greeke indeed.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Nay I am sure she does, she came to him the other
day into the compassed window, and you know he has not
past three or four hairs on his chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Indeed a Tapsters Arithmetic may soon
bring his particulars therein, to a total.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Why he is very young, and yet will he within
three pound lift as much as his brother Hector.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Is he is so young a man, and so old a lifter?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
But to prove to you that Hellen loves him, she
came and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Iuno have mercy, how came it cloven?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Why, you know it is dimpled,
I think his smiling becomes him better than any man
in all Phrigia.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: O he smiles valiantly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Does he not?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: O yes, and it were a cloud in Autumn.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Why go to then, but to prove to you that Hellen
loves Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p:
Troylus will stand to thee
Proof, if you will prove it so.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Troylus? why he esteems her no more than I esteem an addle egg.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p:
If you love an addle egg as well as you love an
idle head, you would eat chickens in the shell.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I cannot choose but laugh to think how she tickled his chin, indeed she has a marvelous white hand I must
needs confess.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Without the rack.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on
his chin.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Alas poor chin? many a wart is richer.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
But there was such laughing, Queen Hecuba
laughed that her eyes ran over.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: With Millstones.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And Cassandra laughed.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p:
But there was more temperate fire under the pot
of her eyes: did her eyes run over too?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And Hector laughed.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: At what was all this laughing?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Marry at the white hair that Hellen spied on
Troylus chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
If it had been a green hair, I should have
laughed too.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
They laughed not so much at the hair, as at his
pretty answer.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: What was his answer?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Quoth she, here is but two and fifty hairs on
your chin; and one of them is white.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: This is her question.

sp.speaker: Pand
sp.p:
That is true, make no question of that, two and
fifty hairs quoth he, and one white, that white hair is
my Father, and all the rest are his Sons. Iupiter quoth
she, which of these hairs is Paris my husband? The forked one quoth he, plucked out and give it him: but there
was such laughing, and Hellen so blushed, and Paris so
chafed, and all the rest so laughed, that it past.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p:
So let it now,
For is has been a great while going by.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Well Cozen,
I told you a thing yesterday, think on it.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: So I does.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
I will be sworn it is true, he will weep you
if it were a man born in April.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
And I will spring up in his tears, if it were a nettle
against May.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Hark they are coming from the field, shall we
stand up here and see them, as they pass toward Illium,
good Niece do, sweet Niece Cressida.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Here, here, here is an excellent place, here we
may see most bravely, I will tell you them all by their names,
as they pass by, but mark Troylus above the rest.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Speak not so loud.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
That is AEneas, is not that a brave man, he is one
of the flowers of Troy I can you, but mark Troylus, you
shall see anon.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
That is Antenor, he has a shrewd wit I can tell
you, and he is a man good enough, he is one of the soundest judgment in Troy whosoever, and a proper man of
person: when comes Troylus? I will show you Troylus anon,
if he see me, you shall see him him nod at me.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Will he give you the nod?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You shall see.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: If he do, the rich shall have, more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
That is Hector, that, that, look you, that there is a
fellow. Go thy way Hector, there is a brave man Niece,
O brave Hector! Look how he looks? there is a countenance; is it not a brave man?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: O brave man!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Is he not? It does a man's heart good, look you
what hacks are on his Helmet, look you yonder, do you
see? Look you there? There is no jesting, laying on, take it
off, who ill as they say, there be hacks.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Be those with Swords?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Swords, anything he cares not, and the devil
come to him, it is all one, by Gods lid it does ones heart
good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris: look
ye yonder Niece, is it not a gallant man too, is it not? Why
this is brave now: who said he came hurt home today?
He is not hurt, why this will do Hellens heart good
now, ha? Would I could see Troylus now, you shall Troylus anon.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
that is Hellenus, I marvel where Troylus is, that is
Helenus, I think he went not forth today: that is Hellenus.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Can Hellenus fight Uncle?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Hellenus no: yes he will fight indifferent, well, I
marvel where Troylus is; hark, do you not hear the
people cry Troylus? Hellenus is a Priest.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: What sneaking fellow comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Where? Yonder? That is Doephobus. It is Troylus! There is a man Niece, hem? Brave Troylus the Prince
of Chivalry.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Peace, for shame peace.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Mark him, not him: O brave Troylus: look
well upon him Niece, look you how his Sword is bloodied, and his Helm more hacked than Hectors, and how he
looks, and how he goes. O admirable youth! he never
saw three and twenty. Go thy way Troylus, go thy way,
had I a sister were a Grace, or a daughter a Goddess, he
should take his choice. O admirable man! Paris? Paris
is dirt to him, and I warrant, Helen to change, would
give money to boot.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Here come more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Asses, fools, dolts, chaff and bran, chaff and
bran; porridge after meat. I could live and die in the eyes
of Troylus. Never look, never look; the Eagles are gon,
Crows and Daws, Crows and Daws: I had rather be
such a man as Troylus, than Agamemnon, and all Greece.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
There is among the Greekes Achilles, a better
man than Troylus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Achilles? a Dray-man, a Porter, a very Camel.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Well, well? Why have you any discretion? have
you any eyes? Do you know what a man is? Is not birth,
beauty, good shape, discourse, manhood, learning, gentleness, virtue, youth, liberality, and so forth: the Spice,
and salt that seasons a man?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Aye, a minced man, and then to be baked with no Date
in the pie, for then the man's dates out.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You are such another woman, one knows not
at what ward you lie.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Upon my back, to defend my belly; upon my
wit, to defend my wiles; upon my secrecy, to defend
mine honesty; my Mask, to defend my beauty, and you
to defend all these: and at all these wards I lie at, at a
thousand watches.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Say one of your watches.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Nay I will watch you for that, and that is one of
the chiefest of them too: If I cannot ward what I would
not have hit, I can watch you for telling how I took the
blow, unless it swell past hiding, and then it is past watching.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You are such another.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord would instantly speak with you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: At your own house.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Good Boy tell him I come, I doubt he be hurt.
Fare ye well good Niece.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Adieu Uncle.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I will be with you Niece by and by.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: To bring Uncle.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Aye, a token from Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: By the same token, you are a Bawd.
sp.p:
Words, vows, gifts, tears, & loves full sacrifice,
He offers in another's enterprise:
But more in Troylus thousand fold I see,
Than in the glass of Pandar's praise may be;
Yet hold I off. Women are Angels wooing,
Things won are done, joys soul lies in the doing:
That she beloved, knows naught, that knows not this;
Men prize the thing ungained, more than it is.
That she was never yet, that ever knew
Love got so sweet, as when desire did sue:
Therefore this maxim out of love I teach;
"Achievement, is command; ungained, beseech.
That though my hearts Contents firm love doth bear,
Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.

div2.stage: Senet. Enter Agamemnon, Nestor, Vlysses, Diomedes, Menelaus, with others.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Princes:
What grief hath set the Jaundice on your cheeks?
The ample proposition that hope makes
In all designs, begun on earth below
Fails in the promised largeness: checks and disasters
Grow in the veins of actions highest reared.
As knots by the conflux of meeting sap,
Infect the sound Pine, and diverts his Grain
Tortive and errant from his course of growth.
Nor Princes, is it matter new to us,
That we come short of our suppose so far,
That after seven years siege, yet Troy walls stand,
Sith every action that hath gone before,
Whereof we have Record, Trial did draw
Bias and thwart, not answering the aim:
And that unbodied figure of the thought
That gave it surmised shape. Why then (you Princes)
Do you with cheeks abashed, behold our works,
And think them shame, which are (indeed) naught else
But the protractive trials of great Ioue,
To find persistive constancy in men?
The fineness of which Metal is not found
In Fortunes love: for then, the Bold and Coward,
The Wise and Fool, the Artist and un-read,
The hard and soft, seem all affined, and kin.
But in the Wind and Tempest of her frown,
Distinction with a loud and powerful fan,
Puffing at all, winnows the light away;
And what hath mass, or matter by itself,
Lies rich in Virtue, and unmingled.

sp.speaker: Nestor.
sp.l: With due Observance of thy godly seat,
Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply
Thy latest words.
In the reproof of Chance,
Lies the true proof of men: The Sea being smooth,
How many shallow bauble Boats dare sail
Upon her patient breast, making their way
With those of Nobler bulk?
But let the Ruffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Thetis, and anon behold
The strong ribbed Bark through liquid Mountains cut,
Bounding between the two moist Elements
Like Perseus Horse. Where is then the saucy Boat,
Whose weak untimbered sides but even now
Corivalled Greatness? Either to harbour fled,
Or made a Toast for Neptune. Even so,
Doth valours show, and valours worth divide
In storms of Fortune.
For, in her ray and brightness,
The Herd hath more annoyance by the Breeze
Than by the Tiger: But, when the splitting wind
Makes flexible the knees of knotted Oaks,
And Flies fled under shade, why then
The thing of Courage,
As roused with rage, with rage doth sympathize,
And with an accent tuned in selfsame key,
Retires to chiding Fortune.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: Agamemnon:
Thou great Commander, Nerve, and Bone of Greece,
Heart of our Numbers, soul, and only spirit,
In whom the tempers, and the minds of all
Should be shut up: Hear what Vlysses speaks,
Besides the applause and approbation
The which most mighty for thy place and sway,
And thou most reverend for thy streched-out life,
I give to both your speeches: which were such,
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece
Should hold up high in Brass: and such again
As venerable Nestor (hatched in Silver)
Should with a bond of air, strong as the Axle-tree
In which the Heavens ride, knit all Greekes ears
To his experienced tongue: yet let it please both
(Thou Great, and Wise) to hear Vlysses speak.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Speak Prince of Ithaca, and be it of less expect:
That matter needless of importless burthen
Divide thy lips; then we are confident
When rank Thersites opes his Mastic jaws,
We shall hear Music, Wit, and Oracle.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: Troy yet upon his basis had been down,
And the great Hectors sword had lacked a Master
But for these instances.
The speciality of Rule hath been neglected;
And look how many Grecian Tents do stand
Hollow upon this Plain, so many hollow Factions.
When that the General is not like the Hive,
To whom the Foragers shall all repair,
What Honey is expected? Degree being vizarded,
The unworthiest shows as fairly in the Mask.
The Heavens themselves, the Planets, and this Centre,
Observe degree, priority, and place,
Insisture, course, proportion, season, form,
Office, and custom, in all line of Order:
And therefore is the glorious Planet Sol
In noble eminence, enthroned and sphered
Amidst the other, whose medicinable eye
Corrects the ill Aspects of Planets evil,
And posts like the Commandment of a King,
Sans check, to good and bad. But when the Planets
In evil mixture to disorder wander,
What Plagues, and what portents, what mutiny?
What raging of the Sea? shaking of Earth?
Commotion in the Winds? Frights, changes, horrors,
Divert, and crack, rend and deracinate
The unity, and married calm of States
Quite from their fixture? O, when Degree is shaked,
(Which is the Ladder to all high designs)
The enterprise is sick. How could Communities,
Degrees in Schools, and Brother-hoods in Cities,
Peaceful Commerce from dividable shores,
The primogenitiue, and due of Birth,
Prerogative of Age, Crowns, Sceptres, Laurels,
(But by Degree) stand in Authentic place?
Take but Degree away, un-tune that string,
And hark what Discord follows: each thing meets
In mere oppugnancy. The bounded Waters,
Should lift their bosoms higher than the Shores,
And make a sop of all this solid Globe:
Strength should be Lord of imbecility,
And the rude Son should strike his Father dead:
Force should be right, or rather, right and wrong,
(Between whose endless jar, Justice resides)
Should lose her names, and so should Justice too.
Then everything includes itself in Power,
Power into Will, Will into Appetite,
And Appetite (an universal Wolf,
So doubly seconded with Will, and Power)
Must make perforce an universal prey,
And last, eat up himself.
Great Agamemnon:
This Chaos, when Degree is suffocate,
Follows the choking:
And this neglection of Degree, is it
That by a pace goes backward in a purpose
It hath to climb. The General is disdained
By him one step below; he, by the next,
That next, by him beneath: so every step
Exampled by the first pace that is sick
Of his Superior, grows to an envious Fever
Of pale, and bloodless Emulation.
And it is this Fever that keeps Troy on foot,
Not her own sinews. To end a tale of length,
Troy in our weakness lives, not in her strength.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Most wisely hath Vlysses here discovered
The Fever, whereof all our power is sick.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: The Nature of the sickness found (Ulysses)
What is the remedy?

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: The great Achilles, whom Opinion crowns,
The sinew, and the fore-hand of our Host,
Having his ear full of his airy Fame,
Grows dainty of his worth, and in his Tent
Lies mocking our designs. With him, Patroclus,
Upon a lazy Bed, the live-long day
Breaks scurril Jests,
And with ridiculous and awkward action,
(Which Slanderer, he imitation calls)
He Pageants us. Sometime great Agamemnon,
Thy topless deputation he puts on;
And like a strutting Player, whose conceit
Lies in his Ham-string, and doth think it rich
To hear the wooden Dialogue and sound
Betwixt his stretched footing, and the Scaffoldage,
Such to be pitied, and over-rested seeming
He acts thy Greatness in: and when he speaks,
It is like a Chime amending. With terms unsquared,
Which from the tongue of roaring Typhoon dropped,
Would seems Hyperboles. At this fusty stuff,
The large Achilles (on his pressed-bed lolling)
From his deep Chest, laughs out a loud applause,
Cries excellent, it is Agamemnon just.
Now play me Nestor; hum, and stroke thy Beard
As he, being dressed to some Oration:
That is done, as near as the extremest ends
Of parallels; as like, as Vulcan and his wife,
Yet god Achilles still cries excellent,
It is Nestor right. Now play him (me) Patroclus,
Arming to answer in a night-alarm,
And then (forsooth) the faint defects of Age
Must be the Scene of mirth, to cough, and spit,
And with a palsy fumbling on his Gorget,
Shake in and out the Rivet: and at this sport
Sir Valour dies; cries, O enough Patroclus,
Or, give me ribs of Steel, I shall split all
In pleasure of my Spleen. And in this fashion,
All our abilities, gifts, natures, shapes,
Severals and generals of grace exact,
Achievements, plots, orders, preventions,
Excitements to the field, or speech for truce,
Success or loss, what is, or is not, serves
As stuff for these two, to make paradoxes.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: And in the imitation of these twain,
Who (as Vlysses says) Opinion crowns
With an Imperial voice, many are infect:
Aiax is grown self-willed, and bears his head
In such a rein, in full as proud a place
As broad Achilles, and keeps his Tent like him;
Makes factious Feasts, rails on our state of War
Bold as an Oracle, and sets Thersites
A slave, whose Gall coins slanders like a Mint,
To match us in comparisons with dirt,
To weaken and discredit our exposure,
How rank soever rounded in with danger.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: They tax our policy, and call it Cowardice,
Count Wisdom as no member of the War,
Fore-stall prescience, and esteem no act
But that of hand: The still and mental parts,
That do contrive how many hands shall strike
When fitness call them on, and know by measure
Of their observant toil, the Enemies weight,
Why this hath not a fingers dignity:
They call this Bed-work, Mappery, closet-ware:
So that the Ram that batters down the wall,
For the great swing and rudeness of his poise,
They place before his hand that made the Engine,
Or those that with the fineness of their souls,
By Reason guide his execution.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Let this be granted, and Achilles horse
Makes many Thetis sons.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What Trumpet? Look Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: From Troy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What would you before our Tent?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Is this great Agamemnons Tent, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Even this.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: May one that is a Herald, and a Prince,
Do a fair message to his Kingly ears?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: With surety stronger than Achilles arm,
Before all the Greekish heads, which with one voice
Call Agamemnon Head and General.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Fair leave, and large security. How may
A stranger to those most Imperial looks,
Know them from eyes of other Mortals?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Aye: I ask, that I might waken reverence,
And on the cheek be ready with a blush
Modest as morning, when she coldly eyes
The youthful Phoebus:
Which is that God in office guiding men?
Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: This Troyan scorns us, or the men of Troy
Are ceremonious Courtiers.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Courtiers as free, as debonair; unarmed,
As bending Angels: that is their Fame, in peace:
But when they would seem Soldiers, they have galls,
Good arms, strong joints, true swords, & Ioues accord,
Nothing so full of heart. But peace AEneas,
Peace Troyan, lay thy finger on thy lips,
The worthiness of praise distains his worth:
If that he praised himself, bring the praise forth.
But what the repining enemy commends,
That breath Fame blows, that praise sole pure transcends.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Sir, you of Troy, call you yourself AEneas?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Aye Greeke, that is my name.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What is your affair I pray you?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Sir pardon, it is for Agamemnons ears.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: He hears naught privately
That comes from Troy.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Nor I from Troy come not to whisper him,
I bring a Trumpet to awake his ear,
To set his sense on the attentive bent,
And then to speak.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Speak frankly as the wind,
It is not Agamemnons sleeping hour;
That thou shalt know Troyan he is awake,
He tells thee so himself.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Trumpet blow loud,
Send thy Brass voice through all these lazy Tents,
And every Greeke of mettle, let him know,
What Troy means fairly, shall be spoke aloud.
We have great Agamemnon here in Troy,
A Prince called Hector, Priam is his Father:
Who in this dull and long-continued Truce
Is rusty grown. He bad me take a Trumpet,
And to this purpose speak: Kings, Princes, Lords,
If there be one amongst the fairest of Greece,
That holds his Honour higher than his ease,
That seeks his praise, more than he fears his peril,
That knows his Valour, and knows not his fear,
That loves his Mistress more than in concession,
(With truant vows to her own lips he loves)
And dare avow her Beauty, and her Worth,
In other arms than hers: to him this Challenge.
Hector, in view of Troyans, and of Greekes,
Shall make it good, or do his best to do it.
He hath a Lady, wiser, fairer, truer,
Than ever Greeke did compass in his arms,
And will tomorrow with his Trumpet call,
Midway between your Tents, and walls of Troy,
To rouse a Grecian that is true in love.
If any come, Hector shall honour him:
If none, he will say in Troy when he retires,
The Grecian Dames are sun-burnt, and not worth
The splinter of a Lance: Even so much.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: This shall be told our Lovers Lord AEneas,
If none of them have soul in such a kind,
We left them all at home: But we are Soldiers,
And may that Soldier a mere recreant prove,
That means not, hath not, or is not in love:
If then one is, or hath, or means to be,
That one meets Hector; if none else, I will be he.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man
When Hectors Grandsire sucked: he is old now,
But if there be not in our Grecian mould,
One Noble man, that hath one spark of fire
To answer for his Love; tell him from me,
I will hide my Silver beard in a Gold Beaver,
And in my Vantbrace put this withered brawn,
And meeting him, will tell him, that my Lady
Was fairer than his Grandam, and as chaste
As may be in the world: his youth in flood,
I will pawn this truth with my three drops of blood.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Now heavens forbid such scarcity of youth.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Fair Lord AEneas,
Let me touch your hand:
To our Pavilion shall I lead you first:
Achilles shall have word of this intent,
So shall each Lord of Greece from Tent to Tent:
Yourself shall Feast with us before you go,
And find the welcome of a Noble Foe.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: Nestor.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What says Vlysses?

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: I have a young conception in my brain,
Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Ulysses.
sp.l: This it is:
Blunt wedges rive hard knots: the seeded Pride
That hath to this maturity blown up
In rank Achilles, must or now be cropped,
Or shedding breed a Nursery of like evil
To over-bulk us all.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Well, and how?

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: This challenge that the gallant Hector sends,
However it is spread in general name,
Relates in purpose only to Achilles.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: The purpose is perspicuous even as substance,
Whose grossness little characters sum up,
And in the publication make no strain,
But that Achilles, were his brain as barren
As banks of Lybia, though (Apollo knows)
It is dry enough, will with great speed of judgment,
Aye, with celerity, find Hectors purpose
Pointing on him.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: And wake him to the answer, think you?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Yes, it is most meet; who may you else oppose
That can from Hector bring his Honour off,
If not Achilles; though it be a sportful Combat,
Yet in this trial, much opinion dwells.
For here the Troyans taste our dearest repute
With their finest Palate: and trust to me Vlysses,
Our imputation shall be oddly poised
In this wild action. For the success
(Although particular) shall give a scantling
Of good or bad, unto the General:
And in such Indexes, although small pricks
To their subsequent Volumes, there is seen
The baby figure of the Giant-mass
Of things to come at large. It is supposed,
He that meets Hector, issues from our choice;
And choice being mutual act of all our souls,
Makes Merit her election, and doth boyle
As it were, from forth us all: a man distilled
Out of our Vertues; who miscarrying,
What heart from hence receives the conquering part
To steel a strong opinion to themselves,
Which entertained, Limbs are in his instruments,
In no less working, than are Swords and Bows
Directive by the Limbs.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: Give pardon to my speech:
Therefore it is meet, Achilles meet not Hector:
Let us (like Merchants) show our foulest Wares,
And think perchance they will sell: If not,
The luster of the better yet to show,
Shall show the better. Do not consent,
That ever Hector and Achilles meet:
For both our Honour, and our Shame in this,
Are dogged with two strange Followers.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I see them not with my old eyes: what are they?

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: What glory our Achilles shares from Hector,
(Were he not proud) we all should wear with him:
But he already is too insolent,
And we were better parch in Affricke Sun,
Than in the pride and salt scorn of his eyes
Should he scape Hector fair. If he were foiled,
Why then we did our main opinion crush
In taint of our best man. No, make a Lottery,
And by device let blockish Aiax draw
The sort to fight with Hector: Among ourselves,
Give him allowance as the worthier man,
For that will physic the great Myrmidon
Who broils in loud applause, and make him fall
His Crest, that prouder than blue Iris bends.
If the dull brainless Aiax come safe off,
We will dress him up in voices: if he fail,
Yet go we under our opinion still,
That we have better men. But hit or miss,
Our projects life this shape of sense assumes,
Aiax employed, plucks down Achilles Plumes.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Now Vlysses, I begin to relish thy advice,
And I will give a taste of it forthwith
To Agamemnon, go we to him straight:
Two Curs shall tame each other, Pride alone
Must tar the Mastiffs on, as it were their bone.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Thersites?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Agamemnon, how if he had Biles (full) all over
generally.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Thersites?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
And those Biles did run, say so; did not the
General run, were not that a botchy core?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Dog.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Then there would come some matter from him:
I see none now.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p:
Thou Bitch-Wolf's-Son, canst you not hear?
Feele then.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
The plague of Greece upon thee thou Mongrel
beef-witted Lord.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p:
Speak then you whinid'st leaven speak, I will
beat thee into handsomeness.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I shall sooner rail thee into wit and holiness:
but I think thy Horse will sooner con an Oration, than you
learn a prayer without book: Thou canst strike, canst
thou? A red Murrain on them thy Jades tricks.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Toads stool, learn me the Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Doest thou think I have no sense thou strikest me thus?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: The Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thou art proclaimed a fool, I think.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Do not Porpentine, do not; my fingers itch.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I would thou didst itch from head to foot, and
I had the scratching of thee, I would make thee the loathsomest scab in Greece.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: I say the Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thou grumblest & railest every hour on Achilles, and thou art as full of envy at his greatness, as Cerberus is at Proserpina's beauty. Aye, that thou barkest at him.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Mistress Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thou shouldest strike him.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Coblofe.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
He would pun thee into shivers with his fist, as
a Sailor breaks a biscuit.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: You whoreson Cur.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Thou stool for a Witch.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Aye, do, do, thou sodden-witted Lord: thou hast
no more brain than I have in mine elbows: An Asinico
may tutor thee. Thou scurvy valiant Ass, thou art here
but to thresh Troyans, and thou art bought and sold among those of any wit, like a Barbarian slave. If thou use
to beat me, I will begin at thy heel, and tell what thou art
by inches, thou thing of no bowels thou.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: You dog.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: You scurvy Lord.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: You Cur.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Mars his Idiot: do rudeness, do Camel, do, do.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Why how now Aiax? wherefore do you this?
How now Thersites? what is the matter man?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: You see him there, do you?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Aye, what is the matter.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Nay look upon him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: So I do: what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Nay but regard him well.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Well, why I do so.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
But yet you look not well upon him: for
whosome-ever you take him to be, he is Aiax.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: I know that fool.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Aye, but that fool knows not himself.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Therefore I beat thee.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters: his
evasions have ears thus long. I have bobbed his Brain
more than he has beat my bones: I will buy nine Sparrows for a penny, and his Piamater is not worth the ninth
part of a Sparrow. This Lord (Achilles) Aiax who wears
his wit in his belly, and his guts in his head, I will tell you
what I say of him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I say this Aiax---

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Nay good Aiax.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Has not so much wit.

sp.speaker: Achil:
sp.p: Nay, I must hold you.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
As will stop the eye of Helen's Needle, for whom
he comes to fight.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Peace fool.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I would have peace and quietness, but the fool
will not: he there, that he, look you there.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: O thou damned Cur, I shall---

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Will you set your wit to a Fools.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: No I warrant you, for a fool's will shame it.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Good words Thersites.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: What is the quarrel?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
I bad thee vile Owl, go learn me the tenure
of the Proclamation, and he rails upon me.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I serve thee not.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Well, go to, go to.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I serve here voluntary.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
Your last service was sufferance, it was not voluntary, no man is beaten voluntary: Aiax was here the
voluntary, and you as under an Impress.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Evenso, a great deal of your wit too lies in your
sinews, or else there be Liars. Hector shall have a great
catch, if he knock out either of your brains, he were as
good crack a fusty nut with no kernel.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: What with me to Thersites?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
There is Vlysses, and old Nestor, whose Wit was
mouldy ere their Grandsires had nails on their toes, yoke
you like draft-Oxen, and make you plough up the war.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: What? what?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Yes good sooth, to Achilles, to Aiax, to ---

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: I shall cut out your tongue.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
It is no matter, I shall speak as much as thou
afterwards.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: No more words Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I will hold my peace when Achilles Brooch bids
me, shall I?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: There is for you Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I will see you hanged like Clot-poles ere I come
any more to your Tents; I will keep where there is wit
stirring, and leave the faction of fools.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: A good riddance.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Marry this Sir is proclaimed through all our host,
That Hector by the fifth hour of the Sun,
Will with a Trumpet, betwixt our Tents and Troy
Tomorrow morning call some Knight to Arms,
That hath a stomach, and such a one that dare
Maintain I know not what: it is trash. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Farewell? who shall answer him?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I know not, it is put to Lottery: otherwise
He knew his man.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: O meaning you, I will go learn more of it.

div2.stage: Enter Priam, Hector, Troylus, Paris and Helenus.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: After so many hours, lives, speeches spent,
Thus once again says Nestor from the Greekes,
Deliver Helen, and all damage else
(As honour, loss of time, travail, expense,
Wounds, friends, and what else dear that is consumed
In hot digestion of this cormorant War)
Shall be stroke off. Hector, what say you to it.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Though no man lesser fears the Greeks than I,
As far as touches my particular: yet dread Priam,
There is no Lady of more softer bowels,
More spongy, to suck in the sense of Fear,
More ready to cry out, who knows what follows
Than Hector is: the wound of peace is surety,
Surety secure: but modest Doubt is called
The Beacon of the wise: the tent that searches
To the bottom of the worst. Let Helen go,
Since the first sword was drawn about this question,
Every tithe soul amongst many thousand dismes,
Hath been as dear as Helen: I mean of ours:
If we have lost so many tenths of ours
To guard a thing not ours, nor worth to us
(Had it our name) the value of one ten;
What merit is in that reason which denies
The yielding of her up.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Fie, fie, my Brother;
Weigh you the worth and honour of a King
(So great as our dread Father) in a Scale
Of common Ounces? Will you with Counters sum
The past proportion of his infinite,
And buckle in a waste most fathomless,
With spans and inches so diminutive,
As fears and reasons? Fie for godly shame?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: No marvel though you bite so sharp at reasons,
You are so empty of them, should not our Father
Bear the great sway of his affairs with reasons,
Because your speech hath none that tells him so.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: You are for dreams & slumbers brother Priest
You fur your gloves with reason: here are your reasons
You know an enemy intends you harm,
You know, a sword employed is perilous,
And reason flies the object of all harm.
Who marvels then when Helenus beholds
A Grecian and his sword, if he do set
The very wings of reason to his heels:
Or like a Star disorbed. Nay, if we talk of Reason,
And fly like chidden Mercurie from Ioue,
Let us shut our gates and sleep: Manhood and Honour
Should have hard hearts, wold they but fat their thoughts
With this crammed reason: reason and respect,
Makes Livers pale, and lustihood deject.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Brother, she is not worth
What she doth cost the holding.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: What is aught, but as it is valued?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: But value dwells not in particular will,
It holds his estimate and dignity
As well, wherein it is precious of itself,
As in the prizer: It is made Idolatry,
To make the service greater than the God,
And the will dotes that is inclinable
To what infectiously itself affects,
Without some image of the affected merit.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I take today a Wife, and my election
Is led on in the conduct of my Will;
My Will enkindled by mine eyes and ears,
Two traded Pilots betwixt the dangerous shores
Of Will, and Judgment. How may I avoid
(Although my will distaste what it elected)
The Wife I chose, there can be no evasion
To blench from this, and to stand firm by honour.
We turn not back the Silks upon the Merchant
When we have spoiled them; nor the remainder Viands
We do not throw in unrespective same,
Because we now are full. It was thought meet
Paris should do some vengeance on the Greekes;
Your breath of full consent bellied his Sails,
The Seas and Winds (old Wranglers) took a Truce,
And did him service; he touched the Ports desired,
And for an old Aunt whom the Greekes held Captive,
He brought a Grecian Queen, whose youth & freshness
Wrinkles Apolloes, and makes stale the morning.
Why keep we her? the Grecians keep our Aunt:
Is she worth keeping? Why she is a Pearl,
Whose price hath launched above a thousand Ships,
And turned Crowned Kings to Merchants.
If you will avouch, it was wisdom Paris went,
(As you must needs, for you all cried, Go, go:)
If you will confess, he brought home Noble prize,
(As you must needs) for you all clapped your hands,
And cried inestimable; why do you now
The issue of your proper Wisdoms rate,
And do a deed that Fortune never did?
Beggar the estimation which you prized,
Richer than Sea and Land? O Theft most base!
That we have stolen what we do fear to keep.
But Thieves unworthy of a thing so stolen,
That in their Country did them that disgrace,
We fear to warrant in our Native place.

div2.stage: Enter Cassandra with her haire about her eares.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Cry Troyans, cry.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: What noise? what shriek is this?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: It is our mad sister, I do know her voice.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Cry Troyans.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: It is Cassandra.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Cry Troyans cry; lend me ten thousand eyes,
And I will fill them with Prophetic tears.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Peace sister, peace.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Virgins, and Boys; mid-age & wrinkled old,
Soft infancy, that nothing can but cry,
Add to my clamour: let us pay betimes
A moiety of that mass of moan to come.
Cry Troyans cry, practise your eyes with tears,
Troy must not be, nor goodly Illion stand,
Our fire-brand Brother Paris burns us all.
Cry Troyans cry, a Helen and a woe;
Cry, cry, Troy burns, or else let Helen go.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Now youthful Troylus, do not these hie strains
Of divination in our Sister, work
Some touches of remorse? Or is your blood
So madly hot, that no discourse of reason,
Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause,
Can qualify the same?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Why Brother Hector,
We may not think the justness of each act
Such, and no other than event doth form it,
Nor once deject the courage of our minds;
Because Cassandra is mad, her brainsick raptures
Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel,
Which hath our several Honours all engaged
To make it gracious. For my private part,
I am no more touched, than all Priams sons,
And Ioue forbid there should be done amongst us
Such things as might offend the weakest spleen,
To fight for, and maintain.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Else might the world convince of levity,
As well my under-takings as your counsels:
But I attest the gods, your full consent
Gave wings to my propension, and cut off
All fears attending on so dire a project.
For what (alas) can these my single arms?
What propugnation is in one man's valour
To stand the push and enmity of those
This quarrel would excite? Yet I protest,
Were I alone to pass the difficulties,
And had as ample power, as I have will,
Paris should never retract what he hath done,
Nor faint in the pursuit.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Paris, you speak
Like one be-sotted on your sweet delights;
You have the Honey still, but these the Gall,
So to be valiant, is no praise at all.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sir, I propose not merely to myself,
The pleasures such a beauty brings with it:
But I would have the soil of her fair Rape
Wiped off in honourable keeping her.
What Treason were it to the ransacked Queen,
Disgrace to your great worths, and shame to me,
Now to deliver her possession up
On terms of base compulsion? Can it be,
That so degenerate a strain as this,
Should once set footing in your generous bosoms?
There is not the meanest spirit on our party,
Without a heart to dare, or sword to draw,
When Helen is defended: nor none so Noble,
Whose life were ill bestowed, or death unfamed,
Where Helen is the subject. Then (I say)
Well may we fight for her, whom we know well,
The worlds large spaces cannot parallel.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Paris and Troylus, you have both said well:
And on the cause and question now in hand,
Have glozed, but superficially; not much
Unlike young men, whom Aristotle thought
Unfit to hear Moral Philosophy.
The Reasons you allege, do more conduce
To the hot passion of distempered blood,
Than to make up a free determination
Betwixt right and wrong: For pleasure, and revenge,
Have ears more deaf than Adders, to the voice
Of any true decision. Nature craves
All dues be rendered to their Owners: now
What nearer debt in all humanity,
Than Wife is to the Husband? If this law
Of Nature be corrupted through affection,
And that great minds of partial indulgence,
To their benumbed wills resist the same,
There is a Law in each well-ordered Nation,
To curb those raging appetites that are
Most disobedient and refractory.
If Helen then be wife to Sparta's King
(As it is known she is) these Moral Laws
Of Nature, and of Nation, speak aloud
To have her back returned. Thus to persist
In doing wrong, extenuates not wrong,
But makes it much more heavy. Hectors opinion
Is this in way of truth: yet never the less,
My sprightly brethren, I propend to you
In resolution to keep Helen still;
For it is a cause that hath no mean dependence,
Upon our joint and several dignities.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Why? there you touched the life of our design:
Were it not glory that we more affected,
Than the performance of our heaving spleens,
I would not wish a drop of Troian blood,
Spent more in her defence. But worthy Hector,
She is a theme of honour and renown,
A spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds,
Whose present courage may beat down our foes,
And fame in time to come canonise us.
For I presume brave Hector would not lose
So rich advantage of a promised glory,
As smiles upon the fore-head of this action,
For the wide worlds revenue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I am yours,
You valiant off-spring of great Priamus,
I have a roisting challenge sent amongst
The dull and factious nobles of the Greekes,
Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits,
I was advertised, their Great general slept,
Whilst emulation in the army crept:
This I presume will wake him.

sp.p:
How now Thersites? what lost in the Labyrinth of thy
fury? shall the Elephant Aiax carry it thus? he beats
me, and I rail at him: O worthy satisfaction, would it
were otherwise: that I could beat him, whilst he railed
at me: 'sfoot, I will learn to conjure and raise Devils, but
I will see some issue of my spiteful execrations. Then there is
Achilles, a rare Engineer. If Troy be not taken till these two
undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget
that thou art Ioue the King of gods: and Mercury, lose
all the Serpentine craft of thy Caduceus, if thou take not
that little little less than little wit from them that they
have, which short-armed ignorance itself knows, is so
abundant scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a
Fly from a Spider, without drawing the massy Irons and
cutting the web: after this, the vengeance on the whole
Camp, or rather the bone-ache, for that methinks is the
curse dependant on those that war for a placket. I have
said my prayers and devil, envy, say Amen: What ho?
my Lord Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p:
Who is there? Thersites. Good Thersites come
in and rail.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
If I could have remembered a guilt counterfeit,
thou wouldst not have slipped out of my contemplation,
but it is no matter, thyself upon thyself. The common
curse of mankind, folly and ignorance be thine in great
revenue; heaven bless thee from a Tutor, and Discipline
come not near thee. Let thy blood be thy direction till
thy death, then if she that lays thee out says thou art a
fair corpse, I will be sworn and sworn upon it she never
shrouded any but Lazars, Amen. Where is Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: What art thou devout? wast thou in a prayer?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Aye, the heavens hear me.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Thersites, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
Where, where, art thou come? why my cheese,
my digestion, why hast thou not served thyself into my
Table, so many meals? Come, what is Agamemnon?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thy Commander Achilles, then tell me Patroclus, what is Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p:
Thy Lord Thersites: then tell me I pray thee,
what is thyself?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Thy knower Patroclus: then tell me Patroclus,
what art thou?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Thou mayst tell that knowest.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: O tell, tell.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I will decline the whole question: Agamemnon commands Achilles, Achilles is my Lord, I am Patroclus knower, and Patroclus is a fool.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: You rascal.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Peace fool, I have not done.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: He is a privileged man, proceed Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Agamemnon is a fool, Achilles is a fool, Thersites is a fool, and as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Derive this? come?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles, Achilles is a fool to be commanded of Agamemon,
Thersites is a fool to serve such a fool: and Patroclus is a
fool positive.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Why am I a fool?

div2.stage: Enter Agamemnon, Vlisses, Nestor, Diomedes, Aiax, and Chalcas.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Make that demand to the Creator, it suffices me
thou art. Look you, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
Patroclus, I will speak with nobody: come in
with me Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Here is such patchery, such juggling, and such
knavery: all the argument is a Cuckold and a Whore, a
good quarrel to draw emulations, factions, and bleed to
death upon: Now the dry Suppeago on the Subject, and
War and Lechery confound all.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Where is Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: Within his Tent, but ill disposed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Let it be known to him that we are here:
He sent our Messengers, and we lay by
Our appertainments, visiting of him:
Let him be told of, so perchance he think
We dare not move the question of our place,
Or know not what we are.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: I shall so say to him.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: We saw him at the opening of his Tent,
He is not sick.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p:
Yes, Lion sick, sick of proud heart; you may
call it Melancholy if will favour the man, but by my
head, it is pride; but why, why, let him show us the cause?
A word my Lord.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.p: What moves Aiax thus to bay at him?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: Achillis hath inveigled his Fool from him.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.p: Who, Thersites?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: He.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.p:
Then will Aiax lack matter, if he have lost his
Argument.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: No, you see he is his argument that has his argument Achilles.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.p:
All the better, their fraction is more our wish
than their faction; but it was a strong counsel that a
Fool could disunite.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p:
The amity that wisdom knits, not folly may
easily untie.
Enter Patroclus. Here comes Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.p: No Achilles with him?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p:
The Elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy:
His leg are legs for necessity, not for flight.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Achilles bids me say he is much sorry:
If anything more than your sport and pleasure,
Did move your greatness, and this noble State,
To call upon him; he hopes it is no other,
But for your health, and your digestion sake;
An after Dinners breath.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Hear you Patroclus:
We are too well acquainted with these answers:
But his evasion winged thus swift with scorn,
Cannot out-fly our apprehensions.
Much attribute he hath, and much the reason,
Why we ascribe it to him, yet all his vertues,
Not virtuously of his own part beheld,
Do in our eyes, begin to lose their gloss;
Yea, and like fair Fruit in an unwholesome dish,
Are like to rot untasted: go and tell him,
We came to speak with him; and you shall not sin,
If you do say, we think him over proud,
And under honest; in self-assumption greater
Than in the note of judgment: & worthier than himself
Here tends the savage strangeness he puts on,
Disguise the holy strength of their command:
And under write in an observing kind
His humorous predominance, yea watch
His pettish lines, his ebbs, his flows, as if
The passage and whole carriage of this action
Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add,
That if he over-hold his price so much,
We will none of him; but let him, like an Engine
Not portable, lie under this report.
Bring action hither, this cannot go to war:
A stirring Dwarf, we do allowance give,
Before a sleeping Giant: tell him so.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: I shall, and bring his answer presently.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: In second voice we will not be satisfied,
We come to speak with him, Ulisses enter you.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: What is he more than another?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.p: No more than what he thinks he is.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p:
Is he so much, do you not think, he thinks
himself a better man than I am?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: No question.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p:
No, Noble Aiax, you are as strong, as valiant, as
wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether
more tractable.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
Why should a man be proud? How doth pride
grow? I know not what it is.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.p:
Your mind is the clearer Aiax, and your vertues
the fairer; he that is proud, eats up himself; Pride is his
own Glass, his own trumpet, his own Chronicle, and
whatever praises itself but in the deed, devours the
deed in the praise.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
I do hate a proud man, as I hate the engendering
of Toads.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: Yet he loves himself: is it not strange?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Achilles will not to the field tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: What is his excuse?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: He doth rely on none,
But carries on the stream of his dispose,
Without observance or respect of any,
In will peculiar, and in self admission.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Why, will he not upon our fair request,
Untent his person, and share the air with us?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Things small as nothing, for requests sake only
He makes important; possessed he is with greatness,
And speaks not to himself, but with a pride
That quarrels at self-breath. Imagined wroth
Holds in his blood such swollen and hot discourse,
That twixt his mental and his active parts,
Kingdomed Achilles in commotion rages,
And batters against itself; what should I say?
He is so plaguey proud, that the death tokens of it,
Cry no recovery.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Let Aiax go to him.
Dear Lord, go you and greet him in his Tent;
It is said he holds you well, and will be led
At your request a little from himself.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: O Agamemnon, let it not be so.
We will consecrate the steps that Aiax makes,
When they go from Achilles; shall the proud Lord,
That bastes his arrogance with his own seam,
And never suffers matter of the world,
Enter his thoughts: save such as do revolve
And ruminate himself. Shall he be worshipped,
Of that we hold an Idol, more than he?
No, this thrice worthy and right valiant Lord,
Must not so stall his Palm, nobly acquired,
Nor by my will assubjugate his merit,
As amply titled as Achilles is: by going to Achilles,
That were to enlard his fat already, pride,
And add more Coals to Cancer, when he burns
With entertaining great Hiperion.
This Lord go to him? Iupiter forbid,
And say in thunder, Achilles go to him.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: O this is well, he rubs the vein of him.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: And how his silence drinks up this applause.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: If I go to him, with my armed fist, I will pash him
over the face.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: O no, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: If he be proud with me, I will feeze his pride: let
me go to him.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: A paltry insolent fellow.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: How he describes himself.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Can he not be sociable?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: The Raven chides blackness.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: I will let his humours blood.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: He will be the Physician that should be the patient.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: If all men were of my mind.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: Wit would be out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p:
He should not bear it so, he should eat Swords
first: shall pride carry it?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: If it would, you would carry half.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.p: He would have ten shares.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: I will knead him, I will make him supple,

he is not
yet through warm.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: Force him with praises, pour in, pour in: his ambition is dry.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: My Lord you feed too much on this dislike.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Our noble General, do not do so.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Why, it is this naming of him doth him harm.
Here is a man, but it is before his face,
I will be silent.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Wherefore should you so?
He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p:
A whoreson dog, that shall palter thus with us, would
he were a Troian.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What a vice were it in Aiax now ---

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: If he were proud.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Or covetous of praise.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Aye, or surly born.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Or strange, or self affected.

sp.speaker: Vl.
sp.l: Thank the heavens Lord thou art of sweet composure;
Praise him that got thee, she that gave thee suck:
Fame be thy Tutor, and thy parts of nature
Thrice famed beyond, beyond all erudition;
But he that disciplined thy arms to fight,
Let Mars divide Eternity in twain,
And give him half, and for thy vigour,
Bull-bearing Milo: his addition yield
To sinewy Aiax: I will not praise thy wisdom,
Which like a bourn, a pale, a shore confines
Thy spacious and dilated parts; here is Nestor
Instructed by the Antiquary times:
He must, he is, he cannot but be wise.
But pardon Father Nestor, were your days
As green as Aiax, and your brain so tempered,
You should not have the eminence of him,
But be as Aiax.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Shall I call you Father?

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: Aye my good Son.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Be ruled by him Lord Aiax.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: There is no tarrying here, the Heart Achilles
Keeps thicket: please it our General,
To call together all his state of war,
Fresh Kings are come to Troy; tomorrow
We must with all our main of power stand fast:
And here is a Lord, come Knights from East to West,
And cull their flower, Aiax shall cope the best.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Go we to Counsel, let Achilles sleep;
Light Bots may sail swift, though greater bulks draw
deep.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Friend, you, pray you a word: Do not you follow the young Lord Paris?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Aye sir, when he goes before me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You depend upon him I mean?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, I do depend upon the Lord.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You depend upon a noble Gentleman: I must
needs praise him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The Lord be praised.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You know me, do you not?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Faith sir, superficially.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Friend know me better, I am the Lord Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I hope I shall know your honour better.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I do desire it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: You are in the state of Grace?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Grace, not so friend, honour and Lordship are my
title: What Music is this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I do but partly know sir: it is Music in parts.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Know you the Musicians.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Wholly sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Who play they to?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: To the hearers sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: At whose pleasure friend?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: At mine sir, and theirs that love Music.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Command, I mean friend.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Who shall I command sir?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Friend, we understand not one another: I am too
courtly, and thou art too cunning. At whose request do
these men play?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
That is to it indeed sir: marry sir, at the request
of Paris my Lord who is there in person; with him the mortal Venus, the heart blood of beauty, loves invisible
soul.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Who? my Cousin Cressida.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
No sir, Helen, could you not find out that by
her attributes?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
It should seem fellow, that thou hast not seen the
Lady Cressida. I come to speak with Paris from the
Prince Troylus: I will make a complemental assault upon
him, for my business seethes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sodden business, there is a stewed phrase indeed.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Fair be to you my Lord, and to all this fair company: fair desires in all fair measure fairly guide them,
especially to you fair Queen, fair thoughts be your
fair pillow.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Dear Lord you are full of fair words.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You speak your fair pleasure sweet Queen:
fair Prince, here is good broken Music.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
You have broke it cozen: and by my life you
shall make it whole again, you shall piece it out with a
piece of your performance. Nel, he is full of harmony.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Truly Lady no.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: O sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Rude in sooth, in good sooth very rude.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.p: Well said my Lord: well, you say so in fits.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I have business to my Lord, dear Queen: my
Lord will you vouchsafe me a word.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Nay, this shall not hedge us out, we will hear you
sing certainly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Well sweet Queen you are pleasant with me,
but, marry thus my Lord, my dear Lord, and most esteemed friend your brother Troylus.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: My Lord Pandarus, honey sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Go to sweet Queen, go to.
Commends himself most affectionately to you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
You shall not bob us out of our melody:
If you do, our melancholy upon your head.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Sweet Queen, sweet Queen, that is a sweet
Queen I'faith ---

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And to make a sweet Lady sad, is a sour offence.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Nay, that shall not serve your turn, that shall it
not in truth la. Nay, I care not for such words, no, no.
And my Lord he desires you, that if the King call for him
at Supper, you will make his excuse.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: My Lord Pandarus?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
What says my sweet Queen, my very, very
sweet Queen?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What exploits in hand, where sups he tonight?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Nay but my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
What says my sweet Queen? my cozen will
fall out with you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: You must not know where he sups.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: With my disposer Cressida.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
No, no; no such matter, you are wide, come your
disposer is sick.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Well, I will make excuse.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Aye good my Lord: why should you say Cressida?
no, your poor disposer is sick.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I spy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You spy, what do you spy: come, give me an
Instrument now sweet Queen.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Why this is kindly done?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
My Niece is horrible in love with a thing you
have sweet Queen.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
She shall have it my Lord, if it be not my Lord
Paris.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
He? no, she will none of him, they two are
twain.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Falling in after falling out, may make them three.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Come, come, I will hear no more of this, I will sing
you a song now.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Aye, aye, prithee now: by my troth sweet Lord thou
hast a fine fore-head.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Aye you may, you may.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Let thy song be love: this love will undo us all.
O Cupid, Cupid, Cupid.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Love? Aye that it shall i'faith.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Aye, good now love, love, nothing but love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
In good troth it begins so.
Love, love, nothing but love, still more:
For O loves Bow,
Shoots Buck and Do:
The Shaft confounds not that it wounds,
But tickles still the sore:
These Lovers cry, o ho they die;
Yet that which seems the wound to kill,
Doth turn o ho, to ha ha he:
So dying love lives still,
O ho a while, but ha ha ha,
O ho groans out for ha ha ha ---- hey ho.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: In love i'faith to the very tip of the nose.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
He eats nothing but doves love, and that breeds
hot blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot
thoughts beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Is this the generation of love? Hot blood, hot
thoughts, and hot deeds, why they are Vipers, is Love a
generation of Vipers?
Sweet Lord whose afield today?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Hector, Deiphoebus, Helenus, Anthenor, and all the
gallantry of Troy. I would fain have armed today, but
my Nell would not have it so.
How chance my brother Troylus went not?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
He hangs the lip at something; you know all
Lord Pandarus?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Not I honey sweet Queen: I long to hear how
they sped today:
You will remember your brothers excuse?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: To a hair.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Queen.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Commend me to your Niece.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I will sweet Queen.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: They are come from field: let us to Priams Hall
To greet the Warriors. Sweet Hellen, I must woe you,
To help unarm our Hector: his stubborn Buckles,
With these your white enchanting fingers touched,
Shall more obey than to the edge of Steel,
Or force of Greekish sinews: you shall do more
Than all the Island Kings, disarm great Hector.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: It will make us proud to be his servant Paris:
Yea what he shall receive of us in duty,
Gives us more palm in beauty than we have:
Yea over-shines ourself.
Sweet above thought I love thee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
How now, where is thy Master, at my Cousin
Cressidas?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No sir, he stays for you to conduct him thither.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: O here he comes: How now, how now?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Sirrah walk off.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Have you seen my Cousin?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: No Pandarus: I stalk about her door
Like a strange soul upon the Stygian banks
Staying for waftage. O be thou my Charon,
And give me swift transportance to those fields,
Where I may wallow in the Lily beds
Proposed for the deserver. O gentle Pandarus,
From Cupids shoulder pluck his painted wings,
And fly with me to Cressid.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Walk here in the Orchard, I will bring her straight.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I am giddy; expectation whirls me round,
The imaginary relish is so sweet,
That it enchants my sense: what will it be
When that the watery palates taste indeed
Loves thrice reputed Nectar? Death I fear me
Sounding destruction, or some joy too fine,
Too subtle, potent, and too sharpe in sweetness,
For the capacity of my ruder powers;
I fear it much, and I do fear besides,
That I shall lose distinction in my joys,
As doth a battle, when they charge on heaps
The enemy flying.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
She is making her ready, she will come straight; you
must be witty now, she does so blush, & fetches her wind
so short, as if she were afraid with a sprite: I will fetch her; it
is the prettiest villain, she fetches her breath so short as a
new taken Sparrow.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom:
My heart beats thicker than a feavorous pulse,
And all my powers do their bestowing lose,
Like vassalage at unawares encountering
The eye of Majesty.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Come, come, what need you blush?
Shames a baby; here she is now, swear the oaths now
to her, that you have sworn to me. What are you gone again, you must be watched ere you be made tame, must
you? come your ways, come your ways, if you draw
backward we will put you in the fills: why do you not speak
to her? Come draw this curtain, & let us see your picture.
Alas the day, how loath you are to offend day light? if
it were dark you would close sooner: So, so, rub on, and kiss
the mistress; how now, a kiss in fee-farm? build there
Carpenter, the air is sweet. Nay, you shall fight your
hearts out ere I part you. The Falcon, as the Tercell, for
all the Ducks in the River: go to, go to.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: You have bereft me of all words Lady.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Words pay no debts; give her deeds: but she will
bereave you of the deeds too, if she call your activity in
question: what billing again? here is in witness whereof the Parties interchangeably. Come in, come in, I will go
get a fire?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Will you walk in my Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: O Cressida, how often have I wished me thus?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Wished my Lord? the gods grant? O my Lord.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: What should they grant? what makes this pretty abruption: what too curious dreg espies my sweet Lady in the fountain of our love?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: More dregs than water, if my tears have eyes.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p:
Fears make devils of Cherubims, they never see
truly.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Blind fear, that seeing reason leads, finds safe
footing, then blind reason, stumbling without fear: to
fear the worst, oft cures the worse.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p:
O let my Lady apprehend no fear,
In all Cupids Pageant there is presented no monster.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Not nothing monstrous neither?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p:
