Nothing but our undertakings, when we vow
to weep seas, live in fire, eat rocks, tame Tigers; thinking it harder for our Mistress to devise imposition
enough, than for us to undergo any difficulty imposed.
This is the monstrosity in love Lady, that the will is infinite, and the execution confined; that the desire is boundless, and the act a slave to limit.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
They say all Lovers swear more performance
than they are able, and yet reserve an ability that they
never perform: vowing more than the perfection of ten;
and discharging less than the tenth part of one. They
that have the voice of Lions, and the act of Hares: are
they not Monsters?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p:
Are there such? such are not we: Praise us as we
are tasted, allow us as we prove: our head shall go bare
till merit crown it: no perfection in reversion shall have
a praise in present: we will not name desert before his
birth, and being born his addition shall be humble: few
words to fair faith. Troylus shall be such to Cressid, as
what envy can say worst, shall be a mock for his truth;
and what truth can speak truest, not truer than Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Will you walk in my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
What blushing still? have you not done talking
yet?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Well Uncle, what folly I commit, I dedicate
to you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I thank you for that: if my Lord get a Boy of
you, you will give him me: be true to my Lord, if he flinch,
chide me for it.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p:
You know now your hostages: your Uncles word
and my firm faith.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Nay, I will give my word for her too: our kindred
though they be long ere they are wooed, they are constant being won: they are Burs I can tell you, they will
stick where they are thrown.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Boldness comes to me now, and brings me
heart: Prince Troylus, I have loved you night and day, for
many weary months.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Hard to seem won: but I was won my Lord
With the first glance; that ever pardon me,
If I confess much you will play the tyrant:
I love you now, but not till now so much
But I might master it; i'faith I lie:
My thoughts were like unbridled children grow
Too head-strong for their mother: see we fools,
Why have I blabbed: who shall be true to us
When we are so unsecret to ourselves?
But though I loved you well, I wooed you not,
And yet good faith I wished myself a man;
Or that we women had men's privilege
Of speaking first. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue,
For in this rapture I shall surely speak
The thing I shall repent: see, see, your silence
Coming in dumbness, from my weakness draws
My soul of counsel from me. Stop my mouth.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And shall, albeit sweet Music issues thence.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pretty i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: My Lord, I do beseech you pardon me,
It was not my purpose thus to beg a kiss:
I am ashamed; O Heavens, what have I done!
For this time will I take my leave my Lord.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Your leave sweet Cressid?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Leave: and you take leave till tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Pray you content you.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: What offends you Lady?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Sir, mine own company.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: You cannot shun yourself.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Let me go and try:
I have a kind of self resides with you:
But an unkind self, that itself will leave,
To be another's fool. Where is my wit?
I would be gone: I speak I know not what.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Well know they what they speak, that speaks
so wisely.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Perchance my Lord, I show more craft than love,
And fell so roundly to a large confession,
To Angle for your thoughts: but you are wise,
Or else you love not: for to be wise and love,
Exceeds man's might, that dwells with gods above.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O that I thought it could be in a woman:
As if it can, I will presume in you,
To feed for ever her lamp and flames of love.
To keep her constancy in plight and youth,
Out-living beauties outward, with a mind
That doth renew swifter than blood decays:
Or that persuasion could but thus convince me,
That my integrity and truth to you,
Might be affronted with the match and weight
Of such a winnowed purity in love:
How were I then up-lifted! but alas,
I am as true, as truths simplicity,
And simpler than the infancy of truth.

sp.speaker: Cr s.
sp.l: In that I will war with you.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O virtuous fight,
When right with right wars who shall be most right:
True swains in love, shall in the world to come
Approve their truths by Troylus, when their rimes,
Full of protest, of oath and big compare;
Wants similes, truth tired with iteration,
As true as steel, as plantage to the Moon:
As Sun today: as Turtle to her mate:
As Iron to Adamant: as Earth to the Centre:
Yet after all comparisons of truth,
(As truths authentic author to be cited)
As true as Troylus, shall crown up the Verse,
And sanctify the numbers.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Prophet may you be:
If I be false, or swerve a hair from truth,
When time is old and hath forgot itself:
When water drops have worn the Stones of Troy;
And blind oblivion swallowed Cities up;
And mighty States characterless are grated
To dusty nothing; yet let memory,
From false to false, among false Maids in love,
Upbraid my falsehood, when they have said as false,
As Air, as Water, as Wind, as sandy earth;
As Fox to Lamb; as Wolf to Heifers Calf;
Pard to the Hind, or Stepdame to her Son;
Yea, let them say, to stick the heart of falsehood,
As false as Cressid.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Go to, a bargain made: seal it, seal it, I will
be the witness here I hold your hand: here my Cousins,
if ever you prove false one to another, since I have taken
such pains to bring you together, let all pitiful goers
between be called to the worlds end after my name: call
them all Panders; let all constant men be Troylusses, all
false women Cressids, and all brokers between, Panders:
say, Amen.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Amen.
Whereupon I will show you a Chamber, which bed, because it shall not speak of your pretty encounters, press
it to death: away.
And Cupid grant all tong-tide Maidens here,
Bed, Chamber, and Pander, to provide this gear.

div2.stage: Enter Vlysses, Diomedes, Nestor, Agamemnon, Menelaus and Chalcas. Florish.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now Princes for the service I have done you,
The advantage of the time prompts me aloud,
To call for recompense: appear it to your mind,
That through the sight I bear in things to love,
I have abandoned Troy, left my possession,
Incurred a Traitors name, exposed myself,
From certain and possessed conveniences,
To doubtful fortunes, sequestering from me all
That time, acquaintance, custom and condition,
Made tame, and most familiar to my nature:
And here to do you service am become,
As new into the world, strange, unacquainted.
I do beseech you, as in way of taste,
To give me now a little benefit:
Out of those many registered in promise,
Which you say, live to come in my behalf.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: What wouldst thou of us Troian? make
demand?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You have a Troian prisoner, called Anthenor,
Yesterday took: Troy holds him very dear.
Oft have you (often have you, thanks therefore)
Desired my Cressia in right great exchange.
Whom Troy hath still denied: but this Anthenor,
I know is such a wrest in their affairs;
That their negotiations all must slack,
Wanting his manage: and they will almost,
Give us a Prince of blood, a Son of Priam,
In change of him. Let him be sent great Princes,
And he shall buy my Daughter: and her presence,
Shall quite strike off all service I have done,
In most accepted pain.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Let Diomedes bear him,
And bring us Cressid hither: Calcas shall have
What he requests of us: good Diomed
Furnish you fairly for this interchange;
Withal bring word, if Hector will tomorrow
Be answered in his challenge. Aiax is ready.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: This shall I undertake, and it is a burthen
Which I am proud to bear.

div2.stage: Enter Achilles and Patroclus in their Tent.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Achilles stands in the entrance of his Tent;
Please it our General to pass strangely by him,
As if he were forgot: and Princes all,
Lay negligent and lose regard upon him;
I will come last, it is like he will question me,
Why such unplausive eyes are bent? why turned on him?
If so, I have derision medicinable,
To use between your strangeness and his pride,
Which his own will shall have desire to drink;
It may do good, pride hath no other glass
To show itself, but pride: for supple knees,
Feed arrogance, and are the proud man's fees.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: We will execute your purpose, and put on
A form of strangeness as we pass along,
So do each Lord, and either greet him not,
Or else disdainfully, which shall shake him more,
Than if not looked on. I will lead the way.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What comes the General to speak with me?
You know my mind, I will fight no more against Troy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What says Achilles, would he aught with us?

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.l: Would you my Lord aught with the General?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: The better.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Good day, good day.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How do you? how do you?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: What, does the Cuckold scorn me?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: How now Patroclus?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Good morrow Aiax?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Aye, and good next day too.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What mean these fellows? know they not
Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: They pass by strangely: they were used to bend
To send their smiles before them to Achilles:
To come as humbly as they used to creep to holy Altars.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What am I poor of late?
It is certain, greatness once fallen out with fortune,
Must fall out with men too: what the declined is,
He shall as soon read in the eyes of others,
As feele in his own fall: for men like butter-flies,
Show not their mealy wings, but to the Summer:
And not a man for being simply man,
Hath any honour; but honoured for those honours
That are without him; as place, riches, and favour,
Prizes of accident, as oft as merit:
Which when they fall, as being slippery standers;
The love that leaned on them as slippery too,
Doth one pluck down another, and together
Die in the fall. But it is not so with me;
Fortune and I are friends, I do enjoy
At ample point, all that I did possess,
Save these men's looks: who do methinks find out
Something not worth in me such rich beholding,
As they have often given. Here is Ulisses,
I will interrupt his reading: how now Vlisses?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Now great Thetis Son.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What are you reading?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: A strange fellow here
Writes me, that man, how dearly ever parted,
How much in having, or without, or in,
Cannot make boast to have that which he hath;
Nor feels not what he owes, but by reflection:
As when his vertues shining upon others,
Heat them, and they retort that heat again
To the first giver.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: This is not strange Vlisses:
The beauty that is born here in the face,
The bearer knows not, but commends itself,
Not going from itself: but eye to eye opposed,
Salutes each other with each others form.
For speculation turns not to itself,
Till it hath travailed, and is married there
Where it may see itself: this is not strange at all.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: I do not strain it at the position,
It is familiar; but at the Authors drift,
Who in his circumstance, expressly proves
That no man is the Lord of anything,
(Though in and of him there is much consisting,)
Till he communicate his parts to others:
Nor doth he of himself know them for aught,
Till he behold them formed in the applause,
Where they are extended: who like an arch reverberate
The voice again; or like a gate of steel,
Fronting the Sun, receives and renders back
His figure, and his heat. I was much rapt in this,
And apprehended here immediately:
The unknown Aiax;
Heavens what a man is there? a very Horse,
That has he knows not what. Nature, what things there are.
Most abject in regard, and dear in use.
What things again most dear in the esteem,
And poor in worth: now shall we see tomorrow,
An act that very chance doth throw upon him?
Aiax renowned? O heavens, what some men do,
While some men leave to do!
How some men creep in skittish fortunes hall,
Whiles others play the Idiots in her eyes:
How one man eats into another's pride,
While pride is feasting in his wantonness
To see these Grecian Lords; why, even already,
They clap the lubber Aiax on the shoulder,
As if his foot were on brave Hectors breast,
And great Troy shrinking.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I do believe it:
For they past by me, as misers do by beggars,
Neither gave to me good word, nor look:
What are my deeds forgot?

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: Time hath (my Lord) a wallet at his back,
Wherein he puts alms for oblivion:
A great sized monster of ingratitudes:
Those scraps are good deeds past,
Which are devoured as fast as they are made,
Forgot as soon as done: perseverance, dear my Lord,
Keeps honour bright, to have done, is to hang
Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail,
In monumental mockery: take the instant way,
For honour travels in a straight so narrow,
Where one but goes abreast, keep then the path:
For emulation hath a thousand Sons,
That one by one pursue; if you give way,
Or hedge aside from the direct forth right;
Like to an entered Tide, they all rush by,
And leave you hindmost:
Or like a gallant Horse fallen in first rank,
Lie there for pavement to the abject, near
Overrun and trampled on: then what they do in present,
Though less than yours in past, must overtop yours:
For time is like a fashionable Host,
That slightly shakes his parting Guest by the hand;
And with his arms outstretched, as he would fly,
Grasps in the comer: the welcome ever smiles,
And farewells goes out sighing: O let not virtue seek
Remuneration for the thing it was: for beauty, wit,
High birth, vigour of bone, desert in service,
Love, friendship, charity, are subjects all
To envious and calumniating time:
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin:
That all with one consent praise new born gauds,
Though they are made and moulded of things past,
And go to dust, that is a little guilt,
More laud than guilt overdusted.
The present eye praises the present object:
Then marvel not thou great and complete man,
That all the Greekes begin to worship Aiax;
Since things in motion begin to catch the eye,
Than what not stirs: the cry went out on thee,
And still it might, and yet it may again,
If thou wouldst not entomb thyself alive,
And case thy reputation in thy Tent;
Whose glorious deeds, but in these fields of late,
Made emulous missions amongst the gods themselves,
And drove great Mars to faction.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Of this my privacy,
I have strong reasons.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: But against your privacy
The reasons are more potent and heroical:
It is known Achilles, that you are in love
With one of Priams daughters.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Ha? known?

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: Is that a wonder?
The providence that is in a watchful State,
Knows almost every grain of Pluto's gold;
Finds bottom in the uncomprehensive deeps;
Keeps place with thought; and almost like the gods,
Do thoughts unveil in their dumb cradles:
There is a mystery (with whom relation
Durst never meddle) in the soul of State;
Which hath an operation more divine,
Than breath or pen can give expressure to:
All the commerce that you have had with Troy,
As perfectly is ours, as yours, my Lord.
And better would it fit Achilles much,
To throw down Hector than Polixena.
But it must grieve young Pirhus now at home,
When fame shall in her Island sound her trump;
And all the Greekish Girls shall tripping sing,
Great Hectors sister did Achilles win;
But our great Aiax bravely beat down him.
Farewell my Lord: I as your lover speak;
The fool slides over the Ice that you should break.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: To this effect Achilles have I moved you;
A woman impudent and mannish grown,
Is not more loathed, than an effeminate man,
In time of action: I stand condemned for this;
They think my little stomach to the war,
And your great love to me, restrains you thus:
Sweet, rouse yourself; and the weak wanton Cupid
Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold,
And like a dew drop from the Lions mane,
Be shook to airy air.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Shall Aiax fight with Hector?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: Aye, and perhaps receive much honour by him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I see my reputation is at stake,
My fame is shroudly gored.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: O then beware:
Those wounds heal ill, that men do give themselves:
Omission to do what is necessary,
Seals a commission to a blank of danger,
And danger like an ague subtly taints
Even then when we sit idly in the sun.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Go call Thersites hither sweet Patroclus,
I will send the fool to Aiax, and desire him
To invite the Troian Lords after the Combat
To see us here unarmed: I have a woman's longing,
An appetite that I am sick withal,
To see great Hector in his weeds of peace;
To talk with him, and to behold his visage,
Even to my full of view. A labour saved.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: A wonder.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Aiax goes up and down the field, asking for
himself.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
He must fight singly tomorrow with Hector,
and is so prophetically proud of an heroical cudgelling,
that he raves in saying nothing.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Why he stalks up and down like a Peacock, a
stride and a stand: ruminates like an hostess, that hath no
Arithmetic but her brain to set down her reckoning: bites his lip with a politic regard, as who should
say, there were wit in his head and it would out; and so
there is: but it lies as coldly in him, as fire in a flint,
which will not show without knocking. The man is undone for ever; for if Hector break not his neck in the combat, he will break it himself in vainglory. He knows
not me: I said, good morrow Aiax; And he replies,
thanks Agamemnon. What think you of this man,
that takes me for the General? He is grown a very
land-fish, languageless, a monster: a plague of opinion, a man may wear it on both sides like a leather
Jerkin.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Thou must be my Ambassador to him Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Who, I: why, he will answer nobody: he professes not answering; speaking is for beggars: he wears
his tongue in his arms: I will put on his presence; let Patroclus make his demands to me, you shall see the Pageant of Aiax.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
To him Patroclus; tell him, I humbly desire the
valiant Aiax, to invite the most valorous Hector, to come
unarmed to my Tent, and to procure safe conduct for his
person, of the magnanimous and most illustrious, six or
seven times honoured Captain, General of the Grecian
Army Agamemnon, etcetera do this.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Ioue bless great Aiax.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Hum.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: I come from the worthy Aehilles.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p:
Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector
to his Tent.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Hum.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: And to procure safe conduct from Agamemnon.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Agamemnon?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: What say you to it.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: God buy you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Your answer sir.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
If tomorrow be a fair day, by eleven o'clock
it will go one way or other; howsoever, he shall pay for
me ere he has me.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Your answer sir.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Fare you well withal my heart.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
No, but he is out a tune thus: what music will
be in him when Hector has knocked out his brains, I know
not: but I am sure none, unless the Fiddler Apollo get his
sinews to make catlings on.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Come, thou shalt bear a Letter to him
straight.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Let me carry another to his Horse; for that is the
more capable creature.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: My mind is troubled like a Fountain stirred,
And I myself see not the bottom of it.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Would the Fountain of your mind were clear
again, that I might water an Ass at it: I had rather be a
Tick in a Sheep, than such a valiant ignorance.

div2.stage: Enter at one doore AEneas with a Torch, at another Paris, Diephoebus, Anthenor, Diomed the Grecian, with Torches.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: See ho, who is that there?

sp.speaker: Dieph.
sp.l: It is the Lord AEneas.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Is the Prince there in person?
Had I so good occasion to lie long
As you Prince Paris, nothing but heavenly business,
Should rob my bed-mate of my company.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: That is my mind too: good morrow Lord
AEneas.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: A valiant Greeke AEneas, take his hand,
Witness the process of your speech within;
You told how Diomed, in a whole week by days
Did haunt you in the Field.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Health to you valiant sir,
During all question of the gentle truce:
But when I meet you armed, as black defiance,
As heart can think, or courage execute.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: The one and other Diomed embraces,
Our bloods are now in calm; and so long health:
But when contention, and occasion meets,
By Ioue, I will play the hunter for thy life,
With all my force, pursuit and policy.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: And thou shalt hunt a Lion that will fly
With his face backward, in human gentleness:
Welcome to Troy; now by Anchises life,
Welcome indeed: by Venus hand I swear,
No man alive can love in such a sort,
The thing he means to kill, more excellently.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: We sympathise. Ioue let AEneas live
(If to my sword his fate be not the glory)
A thousand complete courses of the Sun,
But in mine emulous honour let him die:
With every joint a wound, and that tomorrow.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: We know each other well.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: We do, and long to know each other worse.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This is the most, despitefullest gentle greeting;
The noblest hateful love, that ere I heard of.
What business Lord so early?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: I was sent for to the King; but why, I know not.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: His purpose meets you; it was to bring this Greek
To Calcha's house; and there to render him,
For the enfreed Anthenor, the fair Cressid:
Let us have your company; or if you please,
Haste there before us. I constantly do think
(Or rather call my thought a certain knowledge)
My brother Troylus lodges there tonight.
Rouse him, and give him note of our approach,
With the whole quality whereof, I fear
We shall be much unwelcome.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: That I assure you:
Troylus had rather Troy were borne to Greece,
Than Cressid borne from Troy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: There is no help:
The bitter disposition of the time will have it so.
On Lord, we will follow you.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Good morrow all.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And tell me noble Diomed; faith tell me true,
Even in the soul of sound good fellow ship,
Who in your thoughts merits fair Helen most?
Myself, or Menelaus?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Both alike.
He merits well to have her, that doth seek her,
Not making any scruple of her soilure,
With such a hell of pain, and world of charge.
And you as well to keep her, that defend her,
Not palating the taste of her dishonour,
With such a costly loss of wealth and friends:
He like a puling Cuckold, would drink up
The lees and dregs of a flat tamed piece:
You like a lecher, out of whorish loins,
Are pleased to breed out your inheritors:
Both merits poised, each weighs no less nor more,
But he as he, which heavier for a whore.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You are too bitter to your country-woman.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: She is bitter to her country: hear me Paris,
For every false drop in her bawdy veins,
A Grecians life hath sunk: for every scruple
Of her contaminated carrion weight,
A Troian hath been slain. Since she could speak,
She hath not given so many good words breath,
As for her, Greekes and Troians suffered death.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do,
Dispraise the thing that you desire to buy:
But we in silence hold this virtue well;
We will not commend, what we intend to sell.
Here lies our way.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Dear trouble not yourself: the morn is cold.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Then sweet my Lord, I will call mine Uncle down;
He shall unbolt the Gates.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Trouble him not:
To bed, to bed: sleep kill those pretty eyes,
And give as soft attachment to thy senses,
As Infants empty of all thought.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Good morrow then.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I prithee now to bed.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Are you a weary of me?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O Cressida! but that the busy day
Waked by the Lark, hath roused the ribald Crows,
And dreaming night will hide our eyes no longer:
I would not from thee.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Night hath been too brief.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Beshrew the witch! with venomous wights she (stays,
As hideously as hell; but flies the grasps of love,
With wings more momentary, swift than thought:
You will catch cold, and curse me.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Prithee tarry, you men will never tarry;
O foolish Cressid, I might have still held off,
And then you would have tarried. Hark, there is one up?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: within. What is all the doores open here?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: It is your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: A pestilence on him: now will he be mocking:
I shall have such a life.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
How now, how now? how go maiden-heads?
Hear you Maid: where is my cousin Cressid?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Go hang yourself, you naughty mocking Uncle:
You bring me to do ---- and then you flout me too.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
To do what? to do what? let her say what:
What have I brought you to do?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Come, come, beshrew your heart: you will never be
good, nor suffer others.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Ha, ha: alas poor wretch: a poor Chipochia, hast
not slept tonight? would he not (a naughty man) let it
sleep: a bugbear take him.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Did not I tell you? would he were knocked in the
head. Who is that at door? good Uncle go and see.
My Lord, come you again into my Chamber:
You smile and mock me, as if I meant naughtily.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Come you are deceived, I think of no such thing.
How earnestly they knock: pray you come in.
I would not for half Troy have you seen here.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Who is there? what is the matter? will you beat
down the door? How now, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Good morrow Lord, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Who is there my Lord AEneas? by my troth I
knew you not: what news with you so early?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Is not Prince Troylus here?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Here? what should he do here?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Come he is here, my Lord, do not deny him:
It doth import him much to speak with me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Is he here say you? it is more than I know, I will be
sworn: For my own part I came in late: what should
he do here?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Who, nay then: Come, come, you will do him
wrong, ere you are ware: you will be so true to him, to be
false to him: Do not you know of him, but yet go fetch
him hither, go.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: How now, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: My Lord, I scarce have leisure to salute you,
My matter is so rash: there is at hand,
Paris your brother, and Deiphoebus,
The Grecian Diomed, and our Anthenor
Delivered to us, and for him forth-with,
Ere the first sacrifice, within this hour,
We must give up to Diomeds hand
The Lady Cressida.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Is it concluded so?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: By Priam, and the general state of Troy,
They are at hand, and ready to effect it.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: How my achievements mock me;
I will go meet them: and my Lord AEneas,
We met by chance; you did not find me here.

sp.speaker: AEn.
sp.l: Good, good, my Lord, the secrets of nature
Have not more gift in taciturnity.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Is it possible? no sooner got but lost: the devil
take Anthenor; the young Prince will go mad: a plague
upon Anthenor; I would they had broken his neck.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: How now? what is the matter? who was here?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Ah, ha!

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p:
Why sigh you so profoundly? where is my Lord?
gone? tell me sweet Uncle, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Would I were as deep under the earth as I am
above.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: O the gods! what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Prithee get thee in: would thou hadst never been
born; I knew thou wouldst be his death. O poor Gentleman: a plague upon Anthenor.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Good Uncle I beseech you, on my knees, I beseech you what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Thou must be gone wench, thou must be gone;
thou art changed for Anthenor: thou must to thy Father,
and be gone from Troylus: it will be his death: it will be
his bane, he cannot bear it ..

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: O you immortal gods! I will not go.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Thou must.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I will not Uncle: I have forgot my Father:
I know no touch of consanguinity:
No kin, no love, no blood, no soul, so near me,
As the sweet Troylus: O you gods divine!
Make Cressids name the very crown of falsehood!
If ever she leave Troylus: time, orce and death,
Do to this body what extremity you can;
But the strong base and building of my love,
Is as the very Centre of the earth,
Drawing all things to it. I will go in and weep.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Tear my bright hair, and scratch my praised
cheeks,
Crack my clear voice with sobs, and break my heart
With sounding Troylus. I will not go from Troy.

div2.stage: Enter Paris, Troylus,AEneas, Deiphebus, Anthenor and Diomedes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It is great morning, and the hour prefixed
Of her delivery to this valiant Greeke
Comes fast upon: good my brother Troylus,
Tell you the Lady what she is to do,
And haste her to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Walk into her house:
I will bring her to the Grecian presently;
And to his hand, when I deliver her,
Think it an Altar, and thy brother Troylus
A Priest, there offering to it his heart.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I know what it is to love,
And would, as I shall pity, I could help.
Please you walk in, my Lords.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Be moderate, be moderate.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Why tell you me of moderation?
The grief is fine, full perfect that I taste,
And no less in a sense as strong
As that which causeth it. How can I moderate it?
If I could temporise with my affection,
Or brew it to a weak and colder palate,
The like allayment could I give my grief:
My love admits no qualifying cross; Enter Troylus.
No more my grief, in such a precious loss.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Here, here, here, he comes, a sweet duck.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: O Troylus, Troylus!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
What a pair of spectacles is here? let me embrace too: o heart, as the goodly saying is; O heart, heavy heart, why sighest thou without breaking? where he
answers again; because thou canst not ease thy smart by
friendship, nor by speaking: there was never a truer rime;
let us cast away nothing, for we may live to have need
of such a Verse: we see it, we see it: how now Lambs?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Cressid: I love thee in so strange a purity;
That the blessed gods, as angry with my fancy,
More bright in zeal, than the devotion which
Cold lips blow to their Deities: take thee from me.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Have the gods envy?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Aye, aye, aye, aye, it is too plain a case.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: And is it true, that I must go from Troy?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: A hateful truth.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: What, and from Troylus too?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: From Troy, and Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And suddenly, where injury of chance
Puts back leave-taking, jostles roughly by
All time of pause; rudely beguiles our lips
Of all rejoindure: forcibly prevents
Our locked embrasures; strangles our dear vows,
Even in the birth of our own labouring breath.
We two, that with so many thousand sighs
Did buy each other, must poorly sell ourselves,
With the rude brevity and discharge of our
Injurious time; now with a robbers haste
Crams his rich thievery up, he knows not how.
As many farewells as be stars in heaven,
With distinct breath, and consigned kisses to them,
He fumbles up into a loose adiew;
And scants us with a single famished kiss,
Distasting with the salt of broken tears.

sp.speaker: AEneas
sp.l: within. My Lord, is the Lady ready?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hark, you are called: some say the genius so
Cries, come to him that instantly must die.
Bid them have patience: she shall come anon.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Where are my tears? rain, to lay this wind,
or my heart will be blown up by the root.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I must then to the Grecians?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: No remedy.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: A woeful Cressid amongst the merry Greekes.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: When shall we see again?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hear me my love: be thou but true of heart.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I true? how now? what wicked deem is this?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Nay, we must use expostulation kindly,
For it is parting from us:
I speak not, be thou true, as fearing thee:
For I will throw my Glove to death himself,
That there is no maculation in thy heart:
But be thou true, say I, to fashion in
My sequent protestation: be thou true,
And I will see thee.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: O you shall be exposed, my Lord to dangers
As infinite, as imminent: but I will be true.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And I will grow friend with danger;
Wear this Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: And you this Glove.
When shall I see you?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I will corrupt the Grecian Sentinels,
To give thee nightly visitation.
But yet be true.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: O heavens: be true again?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hear why I speak it; Love:
The Grecian youths are full of quality,
Their loving well composed, with gift of nature,
Flawing and swelling over with Arts and exercise:
How novelties may move, and parts with person.
Alas, a kind of godly jealousy;
Which I beseech you call a virtuous sin:
Makes me afraid.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: O heavens, you love me not!

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Die I a villain then:
In this I do not call your faith in question
So mainly as my merit: I cannot sing,
Nor heel the high Lavolt; nor sweeten talk;
Nor play at subtle games; fair vertues all;
To which the Grecians are most prompt and pregnant:
But I can tell that in each grace of these,
There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil,
That tempts most cunningly: but be not tempted.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Do you think I will:

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: No, but something may be done that we will not:
And sometimes we are devils to ourselves,
When we will tempt the frailty of our powers,
Presuming on their chanceful potency.

sp.speaker: AEneas
sp.l: within. Nay, good my Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come kiss, and let us part.

sp.speaker: Paris
sp.l: within. Brother Troylus?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Good brother come you hither,
And bring AEneas and the Grecian with you.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: My Lord, will you be true?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Who I? alas it is my vice, my fault:
Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion,
I, with great truth, catch mere simplicity;
Whilst some with cunning guild their copper crowns,
With truth and plainness I do wear mine bare:
Fear not my truth; the moral of my wit
Is plain and true, there is all the reach of it.
Welcome sir Diomed, here is the Lady
Which for Antenor, we deliver you.
At the port (Lord) I will give her to thy hand,
And by the way possess thee what she is.
Entreat her fair; and by my soul, fair Greeke,
If ere thou stand at mercy of my Sword,
Name Cressid, and thy life shall be as safe
As Priam is in Illion?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Fair Lady Cressid,
So please you save the thanks this Prince expects:
The lustre in your eye, heaven in your cheek,
Pleads your fair visage, and to Diomed
You shall be mistress, and command him wholly.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Grecian, thou dost not use me courteously,
To shame the seal of my petition towards,
I praising her. I tell thee Lord of Greece:
She is as far high soaring over thy praises,
As thou unworthy to be called her servant:
I charge thee use her well, even for my charge:
For by the dreadful Pluto, if thou dost not,
(Though the great bulk Achilles be thy guard)
I will cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: O be not moved Prince Troylus;
Let me be privileged by my place and message,
To be a speaker free? when I am hence,
I will answer to my lust: and know my Lord;
I will nothing do on charge: to her own worth
She shall be prized: but that you say, be it so;
I will speak it in my spirit and honour, no.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come to the Port. I will tell thee Diomed,
This brave, shall oft make thee to hide thy head:
Lady, give me your hand, and as we walk,
To our own selves bend we our needful talk.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hark, Hectors Trumpet.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: How have we spent this morning
The Prince must think me tardy and remiss,
That swore to ride before him in the field.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It is Troylus fault: come, come, to field with him.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Let us make ready straight.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Yea, with a Bridegroom's fresh alacrity
Let us address to tend on Hectors heels:
The glory of our Troy doth this day lie
On his fair worth, and single Chivalry.

div2.stage: Enter Aiax armed, Achilles, Patroclus, Agamemnon, Menelaus, Vlisses, Nestcr, Calcas, &c.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair,
Anticipating time. With starting courage,
Give with thy Trumpet a loud note to Troy
Thou dreadful Aiax, that the appalled air
May pierce the head of the great Combatant,
And hale him hither.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Thou, Trumpet, there is my purse;
Now crack thy lungs, and split thy brazen pipe:
Blow villain, till thy sphered Bias cheek
Out-swell the colic of puffed Aquilon:
Come, stretch thy chest, and let thy eyes spout blood:
Thou blowest for Hector.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: No Trumpet answers.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: It is but early days.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Is not young Diomed with Calcas daughter?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: It is he, I ken the manner of his gait,
He rises on the toe: that spirit of his
In aspiration lifts him from the earth.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Is this the Lady Cressid?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Even she.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Most dearly welcome to the Greekes, sweet
Lady.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Our General doth salute you with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: Yet is the kindness but particular; it were better she were kissed in general.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: And very courtly counsel: I will begin. So much
for Nestor.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I will take that winter from your lips fair Lady
Achilles bids you welcome.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I had good argument for kissing once.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: But that is no argument for kissing now;
For thus popped Paris in his hardiment.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: O deadly gall, and theme of all our scorns,
For which we lose our heads, to gild his horns.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: The first was Menelaus kiss, this mine:
Patroclus kisses you.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: O this is trim.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: Paris and I kiss evermore for him.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I will have my kiss sir: Lady by your leave.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: In kissing do you render, or receive.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: Both take and give.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I will make my match to live,
The kiss you take is better than you give: therefore no
kiss.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I will give you boot, I will give you three for one.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: You are an odd man, give even, or give none.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: An odd man Lady, every man is odd.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: No, Paris is not; for you know it is true,
That you are odd, and he is even with you.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: You fillip me on the head.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: No, I will be sworn.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: It were no match, your nail against his horn:
May I sweet Lady beg a kiss of you?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: I do desire it.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Why beg then?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Why then for Venus sake, give me a kiss:
When Hellen is a maid again, and his ---

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I am your debtor, claim it when it is due.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: Never is my day, and then a kiss of you.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Lady a word, I will bring you to your Father.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: A woman of quick sense.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Fie, fie, upon her:
There is a language in her eye, her cheek, her lip;
Nay, her foot speaks, her wanton spirits look out
At every joint, and motive of her body:
O these encounterers so glib of tongue,
That give a coasting welcome ere it comes;
And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts,
To every tickling reader: set them down,
For sluttish spoils of opportunity;
And daughters of the game.

div2.stage: Enter all of Troy, Hector, Paris, AEneas, Helenus and Attendants. Florish.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The Troians Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Yonder comes the troop.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Hail all you state of Greece: what shall be done
To him that victory commands? or do you purpose,
A victor shall be known: will you the Knights
Shall to the edge of all extremity
Pursue each other; or shall be divided
By any voice, or order of the field: Hector bad ask?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Which way would Hector have it?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: He cares not, he will obey conditions.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: It is done like Hector, but securely done,
A little proudly, and great deal disprizing
The Knight opposed.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: If not Achilles sir, what is your name?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: If not Achilles, nothing.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Therefore Achilles: but what ere, know this,
In the extremity of great and little:
Valour and pride excel themselves in Hector;
The one almost as infinite as all;
The other blank as nothing: weigh him well:
And that which looks like pride, is courtesy:
This Aiax is half made of Hectors blood;
In love whereof, half Hector stays at home:
Half heart, half hand, half Hector, comes to seek
This blended Knight, half Troian, and half Greeke.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: A maiden battle then? O I perceive you.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Here is sir, Diomed: go gentle Knight,
Stand by our Aiax: as you and Lord AEneas
Consent upon the order of their fight,
So be it: either to the uttermost,
Or else a breach: the Combatants being kin,
Half stints their strife, before their strokes begin.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: They are opposed already.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What Troian is that same that looks so heavy?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: The youngest Son of Priam;
A true Knight; they call him Troylus;
Not yet mature, yet matchless, firm of word,
Speaking in deeds, and deedless in his tongue;
Not soon provoked, nor being provoked, soon calmed;
His heart and hand both open, and both free:
For what he has, he gives; what thinks, he shows;
Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty,
Nor dignifies an impair thought with breath:
Manly as Hector, but more dangerous;
For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes
To tender objects; but he, in heat of action,
Is more vindictive than jealous love.
They call him Troylus; and on him erect,
A second hope, as fairly built as Hector.
Thus says AEneas, one that knows the youth,
Even to his inches: and with private soul,
Did in great Illion thus translate him to me.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: They are in action.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Now Aiax hold thine own.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hector, thou sleep'st, awake thee.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: His blows are well disposed there Aiax.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: You must no more.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Princes enough, so please you.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: I am not warm yet, let us fight again.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: As Hector pleases.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Why then will I no more:
Thou art great Lord, my Fathers sisters Son;
A cousin german to great Priams seed:
The obligation of our blood forbids
A gory emulation betwixt us twain:
Were thy commixion, Greeke and Troian so,
That thou couldst say, this hand is Grecian all,
And this is Troian: the sinews of this Leg,
All Greeke, and this all Troy: my Mothers blood
Runs on the dexter cheek, and this sinister
Bounds in my fathers: by Ioue multipotent,
Thou shouldest not bear from me a Greekish member
Wherein my sword had not impressure made
Of our rank feud: but the just gods gainsay,
That any drop thou borrowedest from thy mother,
My sacred Aunt, should by my mortal Sword
Be drained. Let me embrace thee Aiax:
By him that thunders, thou hast lusty Arms;
Hector would have them fall upon him thus.
Cozen, all honour to thee.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: I thank thee Hector:
Thou art too gentle, and too free a man:
I came to kill thee Cozen, and bear hence
A great addition, earned in thy death.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Not Neoptolymus so admirable,
On whose bright crest, fame with her loudest (O yes)
Cries, This is he; couldst promise to himself,
A thought of added honour, torn from Hector.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: There is expectance here from both the sides,
What further you will do?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: We will answer it:
The issue is embracement: Aiax, farewell.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: If I might in entreaties find success,
As seld I have the chance; I would desire
My famous Cousin to our Grecian Tents.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: It is Agamemnons wish, and great Achilles
Doth long to see unarmed the valiant Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: AEneas, call my brother Troylus to me:
And signify this loving interview
To the expecters of our Troian part:
Desire them home. Give me thy hand, my Cousin:
I will go eat with thee, and see your Knights.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Great Agamemnon comes to meet us here.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: The worthiest of them, tell me name by name:
But for Achilles, mine own searching eyes
Shall find him by his large and portly size.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Worthy of Arms: as welcome as to one
That would be rid of such an enemy.
But that is no welcome: understand more clear
What is past, and what is to come, is strewed with husks,
And formless ruin of oblivion:
But in this extant moment, faith and troth,
Strained purely from all hollow bias drawing:
Bids thee with most divine integrity,
From heart of very heart, great Hector welcome.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I thank thee most imperious Agamemnon.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: My well-famed Lord of Troy, no less to you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Let me confirm my Princely brothers greeting,
You brace of warlike Brothers, welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Who must we answer?

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: The Noble Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O, you my Lord, by Mars his gauntlet thanks,
Mock not, that I affect the untraded Oath,
Your quondam wife swears still by Venus Glove
She is well, but bad me not commend her to you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Name her not now sir, she is a deadly Theme.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O pardon, I offend.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I have (thou gallant Troyan) seen thee oft
Labouring for destiny, make cruel way
Through ranks of Greekish youth: and I have seen thee
As hot as Perseus, spur thy Phrygian Steed,
And seen thee scorning forfeits and subduements,
When thou hast hung thy advanced sword in the air,
Not letting it decline, on the declined:
That I have said unto my standers by,
Lo Iupiter is yonder, dealing life.
And I have seen thee pause, and take thy breath,
When that a ring of Greekes have hemmed thee in,
Like an Olympian wrestling. This have I seen,
But this thy countenance (still locked in steel)
I never saw till now. I knew thy Grandsire,
And once fought with him; he was a Soldier good,
But by great Mars, the Captain of us all,
Never like thee. Let an old man embrace thee,
And (worthy Warrior) welcome to our Tents.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: It is the old Nestor.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Let me embrace thee good old Chronicle,
That hast so long walked hand in hand with time:
Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: I would my arms could match thee in contention
As they contend with thee in courtesy.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I would they could.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Ha? by this white beard I would fight with thee
tomorrow. Well, welcome, welcome: I have seen the time.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: I wonder now, how yonder City stands,
When we have here her Base and pillar by us.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I know your favour Lord Vlysses well.
Ah sir, there is many a Greeke and Troyan dead,
Since first I saw yourself, and Diomed
In Illion, on your Greekish Embassy.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue,
My prophecy is but half his journey yet;
For yonder walls that pertly front your Town,
Yond Towers, whose wanton tops do buss the clouds,
Must kiss their own feet.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I must not believe you:
There they stand yet: and modestly I think,
The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost
A drop of Grecian blood: the end crowns all,
And that old common Arbitrator, Time,
Will one day end it.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: So to him we leave it.
Most gentle, and most valiant Hector, welcome;
After the General, I beseech you next
To Feast with me, and see me at my Tent.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I shall forestall thee Lord Vlysses, thou:
Now Hector I have fed mine eyes on thee,
I have with exact view perused thee Hector,
And quoted joint by joint.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Is this Achilles?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I am Achilles.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Stand fair I prithee, let me look on thee.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Behold thy fill.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Nay, I have done already.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Thou art too brief, I will the second time,
As I would buy thee, view thee, limb by limb.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O like a Book of sport thou wilt read me over:
But there is more in me than thou understandest.
Why doest thou so oppress me with thine eye?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Tell me you Heavens, in which part of his body
Shall I destroy him? Whether there, or there, or there,
That I may give the local wound a name,
And make distinct the very breach, where-out
Hectors great spirit flew. Answer me heavens.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: It would discredit the blessed Gods, proud man,
To answer such a question: Stand again;
Thinkest thou to catch my life so pleasantly,
As to prenominate in nice conjecture
Where thou wilt hit me dead?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I tell thee yea.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Wert thou the Oracle to tell me so,
I would not believe thee: henceforth guard thee well,
For I will not kill thee there, nor there, nor there,
But by the forge that stithied Mars his helm,
I will kill thee everywhere, yea, over and over.
You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag,
His insolence draws folly from my lips,
But I will endeavour deeds to match these words,
Or may I never ---

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Do not chafe thee Cousin:
And you Achilles, let these threats alone
Till accident, or purpose bring you to it.
You may every day enough of Hector
If you have stomach. The general state I fear,
Can scarce entreat you to be odd with him.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I pray you let us see you in the field,
We have had pelting Wars since you refused
The Grecians cause.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Dost thou entreat me Hector?
Tomorrow do I meet thee fell as death,
Tonight, all Friends.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thy hand upon that match.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: First, all you Peers of Greece go to my Tent,
There in the full convive you: Afterwards,
As Hectors leisure, and your bounties shall
Concur together, severally entreat him.
Beat loud the Tambourines, let the Trumpets blow,
That this great Soldier may his welcome know.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: My Lord Ulysses, tell me I beseech you,
In what place of the Field doth Calchas keep?

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: At Menelaus Tent, most Princely Troylus,
There Diomed doth feast with him tonight,
Who neither looks on heaven, nor on earth,
But gives all gaze and bent of amorous view
On the fair Cressid.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Shall I (sweet Lord) be bound to thee so much,
After we part from Agamemnons Tent,
To bring me thither?

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: You shall command me sir:
As gentle tell me, of what Honour was
This Cressida in Troy, had she no Lover there
That wails her absence?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O sir, to such as boasting show their scars,
A mock is due: will you walk on my Lord?
She was beloved, she loved; she is, and doth;
But still sweet Love is food for Fortunes tooth.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I will heat his blood with Greekish wine tonight,
Which with my Scimitar I will cool tomorrow:
Patroclus, let us Feast him to the hight.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Here comes Thersites.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: How now, thou core of Envy?
Thou crusty batch of Nature, what is the news?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Why thou picture of what thou seem'st, & Idol
of Idiot-worshippers, here is a Letter for thee.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: From whence, Fragment?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Why thou full dish of Fool, from Troy.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Who keeps the Tent now?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: The Surgeons box, or the Patients wound.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Well said adversity, and what need these tricks?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Prithee be silent boy, I profit not by thy talk,
thou art thought to be Achilles male Varlet.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Male Varlet you Rogue? What is that?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Why his masculine Whore. Now the rotten
diseases of the South, guts-griping Ruptures, Catarrhs,
Loads of gravel in the back, Lethargies, cold Palsies, and
the like, take and take again, such preposterous discoveries.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p:
Why thou damnable box of envy thou, what
meanest thou to curse thus?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Do I curse thee?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Why no, you ruinous But, you whoreson indistinguishable Cur.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
No? why art thou then exasperate, thou idle,
immaterial skein of Slayed silk; thou green Sarsenet
flap for a sore eye, thou tassel of a Prodigals purse thou:
Ah how the poor world is pestered with such water-flies,
diminutives of Nature.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Out gall.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Finch Egg.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite
From my great purpose in tomorrow's battle:
Here is a Letter from Queen Hecuba,
A token from her daughter, my fair Love,
Both taxing me, and gauging me to keep
An Oath that I have sworn. I will not break it,
Fall Greekes, fail Fame, Honour or go, or stay,
My major vow lies here; this I will obey:
Come, come Thersites, help to trim my Tent,
This night in banqueting must all be spent.
Away Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
With too much blood, and too little Brain, these
two may run mad: but if with too much brain, and too
little blood, they do, I will be a curer of madmen. Here is
Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough, and one that loves
Quails, but he has not so much Brain as ear-wax; and
the goodly transformation of Iupiter there his Brother,
the Bull, the primitive Statue, and oblique memorial of
Cuckolds, a thrifty shoeing horn in a chain, hanging
at his Brothers leg, to what form but that he is, should
wit larded with malice, and malice forced with wit, turn
him to: to an Ass were nothing; he is both Ass and
Ox; to an Ox were nothing, he is both Ox and Ass:
to be a Dog, a Mule, a Cat, a Fitchew, a Toad, a Lizard, an Owl, a Puttock, or a Herring without a Roe,
I would not care: but to be Menelaus, I would conspire
against Destiny. Ask me not what I would be, if I were
not Thersites: for I care not to be the louse of a Lazar,
so I were not Menelaus. Hoy-day, spirits and fires.

div2.stage: Enter Hector, Aiax, Agamemnon, Vlysses, Nestor, Diomed, with Lights.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: We go wrong, we go wrong.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: No yonder it is, there where we see the light.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I trouble you.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: No, not a whit.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: Here comes himself to guide you?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Welcome brave Hector, welcome Princes all.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: So now fair Prince of Troy, I bid goodnight,
Aiax commands the guard to tend on you.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thanks, and goodnight to the Greeks general.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Goodnight my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Goodnight sweet Lord Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Sweet draught: sweet quoth he? sweet sink,
sweet sure.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Goodnight and welcome, both at once, to those
that go, or tarry.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Old Nestor tarries, and you too Diomed,
Keep Hector company an hour, or two.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I cannot Lord, I have important business,
The tide whereof is now, goodnight great Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ulys.
sp.l: Follow his Torch, he goes to Chalcas Tent,
I will keep you company.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Sweet sir, you honour me.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: And so good night.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Come, come, enter my Tent.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
That same Diomed is a false-hearted Rogue, a
most unjust Knave; I will no more trust him when he
leers, than I will a Serpent when he hisses: he will spend
his mouth & promise, like Brabbler the Hound; but when
he performs, Astronomers foretell it, that it is prodigious, there will come some change: the Sun borrows
of the Moon when Diomed keeps his word. I will rather leave to see Hector, than not to dog him: they say,
he keeps a Troyan Drab, and uses the Traitor Chalcas
his Tent. I will after --- Nothing but Lechery? All
incontinent Varlets.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: What are you up here ho? speak?

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.p: Diomed, Chalcas (I think) where is you Daughter?

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.p: She comes to you.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Stand where the Torch may not discover us.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Cressid comes forth to him.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How now my charge?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Now my sweet guardian: hark a word with you.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Yea, so familiar?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: She will sing any man at first sight.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
And any man may find her, if he can take her
life: she is noted.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Will you remember?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Remember? yes.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Nay, but do then; and let your mind be coupled with your words.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: What should she remember?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: List?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Sweet honey Greek, tempt me no more to folly.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Roguery.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I will tell you what.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Fo, fo, come tell a pin, you are a forsworn. -----

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: In faith I cannot: what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: A iugling trick, to be secretly open.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What did you swear you would bestow on me?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I prithee do not hold me to mine oath,
Bid me do not anything but that sweet Greeke.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Good night.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hold, patience.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: How now Troian?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Diomed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: No, no, good night: I will be your fool no more.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Thy better must.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Hark one word in your ear.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O plague and madness!

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: You are moved Prince, let us depart I pray you,
Lest your displeasure should enlarge itself
To wrathful terms: this place is dangerous;
The time right deadly: I beseech you go.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Behold, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Nay, good my Lord go off:
You flow to great distraction: come my Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I pray thee stay?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: You have not patience, come.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I pray you stay? by hell and hell torments,
I will not speak a word.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: And so good night.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Nay, but you part in anger.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Doth that grieve thee? O withered truth!

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: Why, how now Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: By Ioue I will be patient.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Guardian? why Greeke?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Fo, fo, adiew, you palter.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: In faith I do not: come hither once again.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: You shake my Lord at something; will you go?
you will break out.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: She strokes his cheek.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Nay stay, by Ioue I will not speak a word.
There is between my will, and all offences,
A guard of patience; stay a little while.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
How the devil Luxury with his fat rump and
potato finger, tickles these together: fry lechery, fry.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: But will you then?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: In faith I will lo; never trust me else.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Give me some token for the surety of it.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I will fetch you one.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: You have sworn patience.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Fear me not sweet Lord.
I will not be myself, nor have cognition
Of what I feele: I am all patience.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Now the pledge, now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Here Diomed, keep this Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O beauty! where is thy Faith?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I will be patient, outwardly I will.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: You look upon that Sleeve? behold it well:
He loved me: O false wench: give it me again.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: It is no matter now I have it again.
I will not meet with you tomorrow night:
I prithee Diomed visit me no more.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Now she sharpens: well said Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I shall have it.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: What, this?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Aye that.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: O all you gods! O pretty, pretty pledge;
Thy Master now lies thinking in his bed
Of thee and me, and sighs, and takes my Glove,
And gives memorial dainty kisses to it;
As I kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Nay, do not snatch it from me.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: He that takes that, rakes my heart withal.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I had your heart before, this follows it.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I did swear patience.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: You shall not have it Diomed; faith you shall not:
I will give you something else.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I will have this: whose was it?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: It is no matter.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Come tell me whose it was?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: It was one that loved me better than you will.
But now you have it, take it.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: By all Diana's waiting women yond:
And by herself, I will not tell you whose.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Tomorrow will I wear it on my Helm,
And grieve his spirit that dares not challenge it.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Wert thou the devil, and worest it on thy horn,
It should be challenged.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Well, well, it is done, it is past; and yet it is not:
I will not keep my word.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why then farewell,
Thou never shalt mock Diomed again.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: You shall not go: one cannot speak a word,
But it strait starts you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I do not like this fooling.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Nor I by Pluto: but that that likes not me, pleases me best.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What shall I come? the hour.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Aye, come: O Ioue! do, come: I shall be plagued.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Farewell till then.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Good night: I prithee come:
Troylus farewell; one eye yet looks on thee;
But with my heart, the other eye, doth see.
Ah poor our sex; this fault in us I find:
The error of our eye, directs our mind.
What error leads, must err: O then conclude,
Minds swayed by eyes, are full of turpitude.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: A proof of strength she could not publish more;
Unless she say, my mind is now turned whore.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: All is done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: It is.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Why stay we then?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: To make a recordation to my soul
Of every syllable that here was spoke:
But if I tell how these two did co-act;
Shall I not lie, in publishing a truth?
Sith yet there is a credence in my heart:
An esperance so obstinately strong,
That doth invert that test of eyes and ears;
As if those organs had deceptious functions,
Created only to calumniate.
Was Cressed here?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: I cannot conjure Troian.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: She was not sure.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Most sure she was.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Why my negation hath no taste of madness?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Nor mine my Lord: Cressid was here but now.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Let it not be believed for womanhood:
Think we had mothers; do not give advantage
To stubborn Critics, apt without a theme
For depravation, to square the general sex
By Cressids rule. Rather think this not Cressid.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: What hath she done Prince, that can soil our
mothers?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Nothing at all, unless that this were she.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Will he swagger himself out on his own eyes?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: This she? no, this is Diomids Cressida:
If beauty have a soul, this is not she:
If souls guide vows; if vows are sanctimony;
If sanctimony be the gods delight:
If there be rule in unity ifself,
This is not she: O madness of discourse!
That cause sets up, with, and against thyself
By foul authority: where reason can revolt
Without perdition, and loss assume all reason,
Without revolt. This is, and is not Cressid:
Within my soul, there doth conduce a fight
Of this strange nature, that a thing inseparate,
Divides more wider than the sky and earth:
And yet the spacious breadth of this division,
Admits no Orifex for a point as subtle,
As Ariachnes broken woof to enter:
Instance, O instance! strong as Pluto's gates:
Cressid is mine, tied with the bonds of heaven;
Instance, O instance, strong as heaven itself:
The bonds of heaven are slipped, dissolved, and loosed,
And with another knot five finger tied,
The fractions of her faith, orts of her love:
The fragments, scraps, the bits, and greasy relics,
Of her overeaten faith, are bound to Diomed

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: May worthy Troylus be half attached
With that which here his passion doth express?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Aye Greeke: and that shall be divulged well
In Characters, as red as Mars his heart
Inflamed with Uenus: never did young man fancy
With so eternal, and so fixed a soul.
Hark Greek: as much I do Cressida love;
So much by weight, hate I her Diomed,
That Sleeve is mine, that he will bear in his Helm:
Were it a Cask composed by Vulcan's skill,
My Sword should bite it: Not the dreadful spout,
Which Shipmen do the Hurricane call,
Constringed in mass by the almighty Fen,
Shall dizzy with more clamour Neptunes ear
In his descent; than shall my prompted sword,
Falling on Diomed.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: He will tickle it for his concupiscence.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O Cressid! O false Cressid! false, false, false:
Let all untruths stand by thy stained name,
And they will seem glorious.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: O contain yourself:
Your passion draws ears hither.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: I have been seeking you this hour my Lord:
Hector by this is arming him in Troy.
Aiax your Guard, stays to conduct you home.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Have with you Prince: my courteous Lord adieu:
Farewell revolted fair: and Diomed,
Stand fast, and wear a Castle on thy head.

sp.speaker: Vli.
sp.l: I will bring you to the Gates.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Accept distracted thanks.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Would I could meet that rogue Diomed, I
would croak like a Raven: I would bode, I would bode:
Patroclus will give me anything for the intelligence of
this whore: the Parrot will not do more for an Almond,
than he for a commodious drab: Lechery, lechery, still
wars and lechery, nothing else holds fashion. A burning
devil take them.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: When was my Lord so much ungently tempered,
To stop his ears against admonishment?
Unarm, unarm, and do not fight today.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: You train me to offend you: get you gone.
By the everlasting gods, I will go.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: My dreams will sure prove ominous to the day.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: No more I say.

sp.speaker: Cassa.
sp.l: Where is my brother Hector?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Here sister, armed, and bloody in intent:
Consort with me in loud and dear petition:
Pursue we him on knees: for I have dreamt
Of bloody turbulence; and this whole night
Hath nothing been but shapes, and forms of slaughter.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: O, it is true.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Ho? bid my Trumpet sound.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Begone I say: the gods have heard me swear.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows;
They are polluted offerings, more abhorred
Than spotted Livers in the sacrifice.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: O be persuaded, do not count it holy,
To hurt by being just; it is as lawful:
For we would count give much to as violent thefts,
And rob in the behalf of charity.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: It is the purpose that makes strong the vow;
But vows to every purpose must not hold:
Unarm sweet Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Hold you still I say;
Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate:
Life every man holds dear, but the dear man
Holds honour far more precious, dear, than life.
How now young man? meanest thou to fight today?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Cassandra, call my father to persuade.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: No faith young Troylus; doff thy harness youth:
I am today in the vein of Chivalry:
Let grow thy Sinews till their knots be strong;
And tempt not yet the brushes of the war.
Unarm thee, go; and doubt thou not brave boy,
I will stand today, for thee, and me, and Troy.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you;
Which better fits a Lion, than a man.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What vice is that? good Troylus chide me for it.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: When many times the captive Grecian falls,
Even in the fan and wind of your fair Sword:
You bid them rise, and live.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O it is fair play.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Fools play, by heaven Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: How now? how now?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: For the love of all the gods
Let us leave the Hermit Pity with our Mothers;
And when we have our Armours buckled on,
The venomed vengeance ride upon our swords,
Spur them to ruthful work, rein them from ruth.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Fie savage, fie.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hector, then it is wars.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troylus, I would not have you fight today.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Who should with-hold me?
Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars,
Beckoning with fiery truncheon my retire;
Not Priamus, and Hecuba on knees;
Their eyes overgalled with recourse of tears;
Nor you my brother, with your true sword drawn
Opposed to hinder me, should stop my way:
But by my ruin.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Lay hold upon him Priam, hold him fast:
He is thy crutch; now if thou lose thy stay,
Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee,
Fall all together.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: Come Hector, come, go back:
Thy wife hath dreamt: thy mother hath had visions;
Cassandra doth foresee; and I myself,
Am like a Prophet suddenly enrapt,
to tell thee that this day is ominous:
Therefore come back.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: AEneas is a field,
And I do stand engaged to many Greekes,
Even in the faith of valour, to appear
This morning to them.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: Aye, but thou shalt not go,

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I must not break my faith:
You know me dutiful, therefore dear sir,
Let me not shame respect; but give me leave
To take that course by your consent and voice,
Which you do here forbid me, Royal Priam.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: O Priam, yield not to him.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Do not dear father.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Andromache I am offended with you:
Upon the love you bear me, get you in.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl,
Makes all these bodements.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: O farewell, dear Hector:
Look how thou diest; look how thy eye turns pale:
Look how thy wounds doth bleed at many vents:
Hark how Troy roars; how Hecuba cries out;
How poor Andromache shrills her dolour forth;
Behold distraction, frenzy, and amazement,
Like witless Antics one another meet,
And all cry Hector, Hectors dead: O Hector!

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Farewell: yes, soft: Hector I take my leave;
Thou dost thyself, and all our Troy deceive.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: You are amazed, my Liege, at her exclaim:
Go in and cheer the Town, we will forth and fight:
Do deeds of praise, and tell you them at night.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: Farewell: the gods with safety stand about
thee.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: They are at it, hark: proud Diomed, believe
I come to lose my arm, or win my sleeve.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Do you hear my Lord? do you hear?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Here is a Letter come from yond poor girl.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Let me read.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
A whoreson tisick, a whoreson rascally tisick,
so troubles me; and the foolish fortune of this girl, and
what one thing, what another, that I shall leave you one
of these days: and I have a rheum in mine eyes too; and
such an ache in my bones; that unless a man were cursed,
I cannot tell what to think on it. What says she
there?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Words, words, mere words, no matter from
the heart;
The effect doth operate another way.
Go wind to wind, there turn and change together:
My love with words and errors still she feeds;
But edifies another with her deeds.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Why, but hear you?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hence brother lackey; ignomy and shame
Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Now they are clapper-clawing one another, I will
go look on: that dissembling abominable varlet Diomede, has got that same scurvy, doting, foolish young
knaves Sleeve of Troy, there in his Helm: I would fain
see them meet; that, that same young Troian ass, that loves
the whore there, might send that Greekish whoremasterly villain, with the Sleeve, back to the dissembling
luxurious drab, of a sleeveless errant. On the other side,
the policy of those crafty swearing rascals; that stole
old Mouse-eaten dry cheese, Nestor: and that same dog-fox Vlisses is not proved worth a Black-berry. They set
me up in policy, that mongrel cur Aiax, against that
dog of as bad a kind, Achilles. And now is the cur
Aiax prouder than the cur Achilles, and will not arm
today. Whereupon, the Grecians began to proclaim
barbarism; and policy grows into an ill opinion.
Enter Diomed and Troylus. Soft, here comes Sleeve, and the other.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Fly not: for shouldest thou take the River Styx,
I would swim after.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Thou dost miscall retire:
I do not fly; but advantageous care
Withdrew me from the odds of multitude:
Have at thee?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
Hold thy whore Grecian: now for thy whore
Troian: Now the Sleeve, now the Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What art thou Greek? art thou for Hectors match?
Art thou of blood, and honour?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
No, no: I am a rascal: a scurvy railing knave:
a very filthy rogue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I do believe thee, live.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
God a mercy, that thou wilt believe me; but a
plague break thy neck --- for frighting me: what is become of the wenching rogues? I think they have
swallowed one another. I would laugh at that miracle ---- yet in a sort, lechery eats itself: I will seek them.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Go, go, my servant, take thou Troylus Horse;
Present the fair Steed to my Lady Cressid:
Fellow, commend my service to her beauty;
Tell her, I have chastised the amorous Troyan.
And am her Knight by proof.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I go my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Renew, renew, the fierce Polidamus
Hath beat down Menon: bastard Margarelon
Hath Doreus prisoner.
And stands Colossus-wise waving his beam,
Upon the pashed courses of the Kings:
Epistropus and Cedus, Polixines is slain;
Amphimacus, and Thous deadly hurt;
Patroclus taken or slain, and Palamedes
Sore hurt and bruised; the dreadful Sagittary
Appals our numbers, haste we Diomed
To re-enforcement, or we perish all.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Go bear Patroclus body to Achilles,
And bid the snail-paced Aiax arm for shame;
There is a thousand Hectors in the field:
Now here he fights on Galathe his Horse,
And there lacks work: anon he is there afoot,
And there they fly or die, like scaled skulls,
Before the belching Whale; then is he yonder,
And there the straying Greekes, ripe for his edge,
Fall down before him, like the mowers swath;
Here, there, and everywhere, he leaves and takes;
Dexterity so obeying appetite,
That what he will, he does, and does so much,
That proof is called impossibility.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: O, courage, courage Princes: great Achilles
Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance;
Patroclus wounds have roused his drowsy blood,
Together with his mangled Myrmidons,
That noseless, handless, hacked and chipped, come to him;
Crying on Hector. Aiax hath lost a friend,
And foams at mouth, and he is armed, and at it:
Roaring for Troylus; who hath done today.
Mad and fantastic execution;
Engaging and redeeming of himself,
With such a careless force, and forceless care,
As if that luck in very spite of cunning, bad him win all.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Troylus, thou coward Troylus.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Aye, there, there.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: So, so, we draw together.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Where is this Hector?
Come, come, thou boy-queller, show thy face:
Know what it is to meet Achilles angry.
Hector, where is Hector? I will none but Hector.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Troylus, thou coward Troylus, show thy head.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Troylus, I say, where is Troylus?
