sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: What wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: I would correct him.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Were I the General,
Thou shouldest have my office,
Ere that correction: Troylus I say, what Troylus?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O traitor Diomed!
Turn thy false face thou traitor,
And pay thy life thou owest me for my horse.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Ha, art thou there?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: I will fight with him alone, stand Diomed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: He is my prize, I will not look upon.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come both you cogging Greekes, have at you
both.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Yea Troylus? O well fought my youngest Brother.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Now do I see thee; have at thee Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Pause if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I do disdain thy courtesy, proud Troian;
Be happy that my arms are out of use:
My rest and negligence befriends thee now,
But thou anon shalt hear of me again:
Till when, go seek thy fortune.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Fare thee well:
I would have been much more a fresher man,
Had I expected thee: how now my Brother?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Aiax hath taken AEneas; shall it be?
No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven,
He shall not carry him: I will be taken too,
Or bring him off: Fate hear me what I say;
I wreak not, though thou end my life today.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Stand, stand, thou Greeke,
Thou art a goodly mark:
No? wilt thou not? I like thy armour well,
I will frush it, and unlock the rivets all,
But I will be master of it: wilt thou not beast abide?
Why then fly on, I will hunt thee for thy hide.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Come here about me you my Myrmidons:
Mark what I say; attend me where I wheel:
Strike not a stroke, but keep yourselves in breath;
And when I have the bloody Hector found,
Impale him with your weapons round about:
In fellest manner execute your arm.
Follow me sirs, and my proceedings eye;
It is decreed, Hector the great must die.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
The Cuckold and the Cuckold maker are at it:
now bull, now dog, low; Paris low; now my double henned sparrow; low Paris, low; the bull has the
game: ware horns ho?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Turn slave and fight.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: A Bastard Son of Priams.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p:
I am a Bastard too, I love Bastards, I am a Bastard begot, Bastard instructed, Bastard in mind, Bastard
in valour, in everything illegitimate: one Bear will not
bite another, and wherefore should one Bastard? take
heed, the quarrel is most ominous to us: if the Son of a
whore fight for a whore, he tempts judgment: farewell
Bastard.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: The devil take thee coward.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Most putrefied core so fair without:
Thy goodly armour thus hath cost thy life.
Now is my day's work done; I will take good breath:
Rest Sword, thou hast thy fill of blood and death.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Look Hector how the Sun begins to set;
How ugly night comes breathing at his heels,
Even with the veil and darkening of the Sun.
To close the day up, Hectors life is done.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I am unarmed, forgo this vantage Greeke.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Strike fellows, strike, this is the man I seek.
So Illion fall thou: now Troy sink down;
Here lies thy heart, thy sinews, and thy bone.
On Myrmidons, cry you all a main,
Achilles hath the mighty Hector slain.
Hark, a retreat upon our Grecian part.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.l: The Troian Trumpets sounds the like my Lord.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: The dragon wing of night overspreads the earth
And stickler-like the Armies separates
My half supped Sword, that frankly would have fed,
Pleased with this dainty bed; thus goes to bed.
Come, tie his body to my horses tail;
Along the field, I will the Troian trail.

div2.stage: Enter Agamemnon, Aiax, Menelaus, Nestor, Diomed, and the rest marching.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Hark, hark, what shout is that?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Peace Drums.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Achilles, Achilles, Hector is slain, Achilles.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: The bruit is, Hector is slain, and by Achilles.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: If it be so, yet bragless let it be:
Great Hector was a man as good as he.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: March patiently along; let one be sent
To pray Achilles see us at our Tent.
If in his death the gods have us befriended,
Great Troy is ours, and our sharpe wars are ended.

div2.stage: Enter AEneas, Paris, Anthenor and Deiphoebus.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: Stand ho, yet are we masters of the field,
Never go home; here starve we out the night.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hector is slain.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hector? the gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: He is dead: and at the murtherers Horses tail,
In beastly sort, dragged through the shameful Field.
Frown on you heavens, effect your rage with speed:
Sit gods upon your thrones, and smile at Troy.
I say at once, let your brief plagues be mercy,
And linger not our sure destructions on.

sp.speaker: AEne.
sp.l: My Lord, you do discomfort all the Host.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: You understand me not, that tell me so:
I do not speak of flight, of fear, of death,
But dare all imminence that gods and men,
Address their dangers in. Hector is gone:
Who shall tell Priam so? or Hecuba?
Let him that will a screech-owle aye be called,
Go in to Troy, and say there, Hecctor is dead:
There is a word will Priam turn to stone;
Make wells, and Niobes of the maids and wives;
Cool statues of the youth: and in a word,
Scar Troy out of itself. But march away,
Hector is dead: there is no more to say.
Stay yet: you vile abominable Tents,
Thus proudly pitched upon our Phrygian plains:
Let Titan rise as early as he dare,
I will through, and through you; & thou great sized coward:
No space of Earth shall sunder our two hates,
I will haunt thee, like a wicked conscience still,
That mouldeth goblins swift as frenzies thoughts.
Strike a free march to Troy, with comfort go:
Hope of revenge, shall hide our inward woe.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: But hear you? hear you?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hence broker, lackey, ignominy, and shame
Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
A goodly medicine for mine aching bones: o world,
world, world! thus is the poor agent despised: O traitors and bawds; how earnestly are you set a-work, and
how ill requited? why should our endeavour be so desired,
and the performance so loathed? What Verse for it? what
instance for it? let me see.
Full merrily the humble Bee doth sing,
Till he hath lost his honey, and his sting.
And being once subdued in armed tail,
Sweet honey, and sweet notes together fail.
Good traders in the flesh, set this in your painted clothes;
As many as be here of Panders hall,
Your eyes half out, weep out at Pandar's fall:
Or if you cannot weep, yet give some groans;
Though not for me, yet for your aching bones:
Brethren and sisters of the hold-door trade,
Some two months hence, my will shall here be made:
It should be now, but that my fear is this:
Some galled Goose of Winchester would hiss:
Till then, I will sweat, and seek about for eases;
And at that time bequeath you my diseases.
